title: Letter to local council leaders: inspiring the Big Society
summary: Letter to councils asking them to consult their communities on how they would like to improve their local area
body:
On 15 December 2010, the Department for Communities and Local Government issued an invitation to local authorities under the Sustainable Communities Act 2007. This letter details the invitation, which asks councils to:

 consult their communities on how they would like to improve their local area
 take whatever action they deem appropriate
 ask the government to remove any bureaucratic barrier which is stopping them

ignoreDCLG page title: Next Steps: Firefighter pension reforms and employee contributions
title: Firefighters' pension reforms: intention to consult
summary: Letter outlining the government's intention to consult on raising employee contribution rates for firefighters' pensions
body:
Following the written minsiterial statement made by the Chief Secretary to the Treasury on 19 July 2011, this letter sets out the Department for Communities and Local Government's intention to consult in August 2011 on proposed increases to employee contribution rates for the firefighters' pension schemes in 2012-13.

This letter also outlines the proposed process for further discussions on the savings to be generated in 2013-14 and 2014-15, and on the wider reforms arising from Lord Hutton's report.

ignoreDCLG page title: The Housing Revenue Account Subsidy Determination 2009 to 2010 and the Item 8 Credit and Item 8 Debit (General) Determination 2009 to 2010: Amending Determinations 2011
title: The housing revenue account subsidy determination 2009 to 2010: technical documents
summary: Technical amendments about interest rate calculations for housing borrowing
body:
The Department for Communities and Local Governement (DCLG) has made a change retrospectively so that the calculation of the consolidated interest rate for housing borrowing continues to exclude all private finance initiatives (PFIs).

This is following the introduction of international financial reporting atandards, which would have brought PFI schemes into the calculations from 1 April 2009. This could have an adverse effect on some areas of local authorities' finances.

DCLG consulted on the change over summer 2010 and it has now been included in these documents.
attachment_1_title: The housing revenue account subsidy determination 2009 to 2010 amending determination 2011
attachment_2_title: The item 8 credit and item 8 debit (general) determination 2009 to 2010 amending determination 2011

ignoreDCLG page title: Call for evidence: Improving the energy performance of bulidings regime
title: Call for evidence: improving the energy performance of buildings regime
summary: Letter from Lord Marland and Andrew Stunell seeking views on how to improve the energy performance of buildings regime
body:
The Department for Communities and Local Government and the Department of Energy and Climate Change (DECC) are working together on making improvements to the energy performance of buildings regime in order to support the Green Deal.

The Green Deal is the government's scheme to enable private firms to offer consumers energy efficiency improvements to their homes, community spaces and businesses at no upfront cost, and recoup payments through a charge in instalments on the energy bill.

Andrew Stunell OBE MP and Lord Marland have written an open letter inviting external partner views on how to do this, for response by 21 December 2010.
attachment_1_title: Letter from Lord Marland and Andrew Stunell seeking views on how to improve the energy performance of buildings regime

body:
This circular:

* draws attention to the changes made by the Building (Amendment) Regulations 2011 (SI 2011/1515)
* confirms that the approval of the Approved Documents is unaffected by these changes
* announces further provisions for self-certification

The Building (Amendment) Regulations 2011 make minor amendments to the Building Regulations 2010 (S.I. 2010/2214), and should be read in conjunction with the Building Regulations 2010.

* sets out and explains 2 sets of regulations (SI 2010/2214) and (SI 2010/2215) which consolidate the Building Regulations 2000 (SI 2000/2531) and subsequent amendments to those regulations, and the Building (Approved Inspectors etc) Regulations 2000 (SI 2000/2532) and subsequent amendments to those regulations
* explains the transitional provisions
* confirms the continued approval of the Approved Documents and approved methodologies, circumstances, procedures and manners of recording under specific regulations in the Building Regulations
* announces further provisions for self-certification This is a priced publication available from TSO (The Stationery Office), PO Box 29, Norwich NR3 1GN.

ignoreDCLG page title: Code of Recommended Practice on Local Authority Publicity
title: Recommended code of practice for local authority publicity
body:
The Publicity Code provides guidance on the content, style, distribution and cost of local authority publicity. Local authorities are required by legislation to consider the Code in coming to any decision on publicity, which is defined as any communication, in whatever form, addressed to the public or a section of the public.

A consultation with local authority organisations on a draft revised Code closed on 10 November 2010. The Communities and Local Government Select Committee also undertook a short inquiry looking at the draft revised Code on 6 December 2010. Their report was published on 27 January 2011 and is available from Parliament's web-site.

A revised Code was laid before Parliament on 11 February. It was approved by both Houses of Parliament on 30 March and came into force on 31 March 2011.

This is a priced publication available from TSO (The Stationery Office), PO Box 29, Norwich NR3 1GN. Order through the Parliamentary Hotline (Lo-call): 08457 023 474, fax: 0870 600 5533, textphone 0870 240 3701, email:book.orders@tso.co.uk or visit www.tsoshop.co.uk to buy online.
ignoretype from DCLG: Circular and official letters, Good practice and guidance

title: Support package for local firms and families to help rebuild their communities
body:
This letter was sent by the Secretary of State to Leaders of local authorities and fire authorites who were affected by the riots. It informs them of their eligibility under the terms of the recovery scheme and details the package of support available.

The letter, terms of the recovery scheme, guidance for local authorities on the high street support scheme and an example application form for local authorities to issue to impacted businesses can be downloaded below.

**Please note:** The 'High Street Support Scheme - guidance for Local Authorities' and 'Recovery Scheme for businesses - application form' were updated on 30 September 2011 to reflect the payment deadline extension from 7 November 2011 to 3 January 2012.

ignoreDCLG page title: Sustainable Operations Policy Statement - February 2011
title: Sustainable operations policy statement: February 2011
body:
This policy statement commits the Department to maintaining its Environmental Management System to ISO 14001, and more specifically to the prevention of pollution and compliance with all relevant legislation, regulations and commitments associated wth the programme for Sustainable Operations on the Government Estate (SOGE). The statement outlines the Department for Communities and Local Government's (DCLG's) duty to continually improve performance by identifying and monitoring its negative environmental impacts and setting targets and objectives to reduce these.

The policy statement applies to all individuals working on the CLG estate.
ignoretype from DCLG: Circular and official letters, Legislation and policy
attachment_1_title: Sustainable Operations Policy Statement - February 2011

ignoreDCLG page title: Capital Finance Amendment Regulations (SI 2012/265) - Commentary
title: Capital finance amendment regulations: commentary
body:
This informal commentary summarises the intended effects of the 2012 Capital Finance Amendment Regulations: Statutory Instrument 2012 number 265.

This legislation covers local authorities in England only.

The main effects are to bring securitisation within the capital finance framework, relax the rules on bond investments, and clarify the definition of capital expenditure. Securitisation is the exchange of future revenues for an immediate lump sum payment.
ignoretype from DCLG: Circular and official letters, Legislation and policy
attachment_1_title: Capital Finance Amendment Regulations (SI 2012/265) - Commentary

ignoreDCLG page title: Circular 01/2012: The Building Act 1984, Building (Amendment) Regulations 2012
title: The Building Act 1984, Building (Amendment) Regulations 2012: circular 01/2012
body:
The purpose of this Circular is to:

  * draw attention to the fact that the amendments apply in England and to excepted energy buildings in Wales
  * amend the name of  the registration body Building Engineering Services Competence Accreditation Limited to Building Engineering Services Competence Assessment Limited wherever it appears in Schedule 3 to the Building Regulations 2010
  * remove the name of Benchmark Certification Limited in respect of a number of types of work in Schedule 3 to the Building Regulations 2010.

The Building (Amendment) Regulations 2012 make minor amendments to the Building Regulations 2010 (SI 2010/2214), and should be read in conjunction with the Building Regulations 2010 (see links, top right, under 'On other sites').

This is a priced publication available from TSO (The Stationery Office), PO Box 29, Norwich NR3 1GN. Order through the Parliamentary Hotline (Lo-call): 08457 023 474, fax: 0870 600 5533, textphone 0870 240 3701, email: book.orders@tso.co.uk or visit www.tsoshop.co.uk to buy online.

ignoreDCLG page title: Replacement Appendix D to Department of the Environment Circular 09/95: General Development Consolidation Order 1995
title: Replacement Appendix D to Department of the Environment: circular 09/95
body:
This document replaces Appendix D of _Circular 09/95: General Development Consolidation Order 1995_ in providing guidance on the use of 'article 4 directions', which withdraw permitted development rights granted by Schedule 2 to the _Town and Country Planning (General Permitted Development) Order 1995_ as amended. It contains information about associated compensation arrangements and provides 'model' article 4 directions.

This guidance was published on 4 November 2010 to reflect changes to the article 4 direction procedure and compensation arrangements introduced by _Statutory Instruments 2010/654_ and _2010/2135_. This has been updated to correct a factual error in the previous version - specifically paragraph 5.1 to reflect that regulations require the same procedure is undertaken for making a direction cancelling another direction (whereas previously the guidance stated in error that reconsultation is not required in doing so).

This document is relevant to both planning practitioners and those affected by article 4 directions.
ignoretype from DCLG: Circular and official letters, Legislation and policy
attachment_1_title: Replacement Appendix D to Department of the Environment Circular 09/95: General Development Consolidation Order 1995

ignoreDCLG page title: Local government contribution to efficiencies in 2010-11
title: Local government contribution to efficiencies in 2010 to 2011
body:
The Government has published details of the Â£1.166bn Local Government contribution to the Â£6.2bn cross government savings in 2010/11 needed to tackle the UK's record deficit in order to restore confidence in the economy and support the recovery.

The information listed in the documents and tables below set out the basis on which the Government will implement reductions to individual local authority grant allocations, as announced in a Written Ministerial Statement made by the Secretary of Statement on Thursday 10 June 2010.

The Government recognises that it will be challenging for local authorities (along with other parts of the public sector) to make these reductions in-year. However, the Government is clear that these reductions are necessary for the reasons set out above. The Government believes that it is for local authorities to decide where their priorities and opportunities for efficiencies lie across the totality of their responsibilities.

To support local authorities to re-shape their budgets, the Government aims to give authorities certainty about their grant reductions as a matter of urgency, so that they can make the necessary decisions as quickly as possible. The Government has also received representations from local government to provide certainty urgently.

The Government will not be consulting authorities on the reductions to grants or funding streams. However, in relation to those grant streams where reductions are necessary, the Government considers it prudent to publish amended allocations and to allow local authorities to comment on the accuracy of the figures before they are implemented.

Authorities have been asked to let the Department know by 5pm on Thursday 24 June if they believe that there are errors in the figures.

ignoreDCLG page title: Government Procurement Card spending data 12 May 2010 to 31 January 2011
title: Government procurement card spending data May 2010 to January 2011
body:
**Guidance on Department for Communities and Local Government and Government Offices spending data 2010-11**

HM Treasury requires that all central government departments should publish details of their April - September 2010 spending for transactions over Â£25,000 by the end of October 2010, and thereafter publish monthly data by the last working day of each month. This Department has lowered its threshold and publishes its transactions over Â£500.

The Department for Communities and Local Government has published, on 28 February 2011, its spending over Â£500 data for January and for Government Procurement Card expenditure since May 2010.

The Department's arm's length bodies will each be responsible for publishing their own spending data, both on their own websites and on Data.gov.uk.

Points to note on this report:

  * Currently listed below is the spending report for Government Procurement Cards. The Department for Communities and Local Government is the first Whitehall department to publish online details of corporate credit card expenditure.
  * Spend data for Government Procurement Cards covers the period 12 May 2010 to 31 January 2011.
  * Government Procurement Cards are available to all UK public sector organisations, including central government, local government and the NHS.
  * Government Procurement Cards are issued to employees with responsibility for buying goods and services. These employees are made accountable for their activities, supported by management information that provides details of every transaction.

This data will continue to be published, on a month by month basis beginning with February data (published in March), along with the department's monthly spend data.

ignoreDCLG page title: DCLG's second statement of new regulation
title: DCLG's second statement of new regulation
body:
The Second Statement of New Regulation is a forward look of all regulations (including measures which are deregulatory) being introduced by the Department which impact on businesses. They are scheduled to come into force between 1 July and 31 December 2011.

This is published every six months to give businesses an indication of when regulations affecting them will be coming into effect.

The headline figures show:

  * the measures we are introducing this year will reduce burdens on businesses by an estimated Â£4.26 million per year
  * of the five measures we are introducing, three measures are estimated to have net cost savings to business.
attachment_1_title: DCLG's Second Statement of New Regulation

ignoreDCLG page title: Department for Communities and Local Government and Government Offices spending data Q1 2010-11
title: Spending data for DCLG and government offices Q1 2010 to 2011
body:
**Guidance on Communities and Local Government and Government Offices spending data 2010-11**

HM Treasury requires that all central government departments should publish details of their April - September 2010 spend transaction over Â£25k by the end of October 2010, and, thereafter, publish monthly data by the last working day of each month.

Local Authorities will follow a similar process but will be required to publish spend over the lower Â£500 threshold from January 2011.

The Secretary of State for Communities and Local Government has determined that DCLG and its arms length bodies will publish transactions at the lower Â£500 threshold, in line with the local authorities, and will also publish ahead of other government departments, publishing April - June spend data at the end of September 2010.

The Department's arms length bodies will each be responsible for publishing their own spend data, both on their own website and data.gov, and will publish April - September 2010 spend data at the end of October 2010, in line with other government departments.

Points to note on this report:

  * Currently listed below are the spending reports for Q1 April - June 2010.
  * HMT have set out a prescriptive format for this Transparency report to ensure consistency across Whitehall. This format is set out in the technical report definition document (see related download below).
  * Over Â£500 Transparency Spend Data is taken from SAP's General Ledger payment transactions.
  * As required by HM Treasury, the data relates to Accounts Payable payment and credit note transactions for grants and procurement expenditure, recorded at the time the transaction was processed on SAP. The data excludes any subsequent journal transactions and Accounts Receivable receipts.
  * HM Treasury are keen to ensure that there is a presumption that all data will be published and have set out only a limited range of spend types that can be excluded (redacted) from this report. These are listed in Extract from the Treasury's guidance on Data Inclusions and Redactions document (see related download below).
  * There remains however uncertainty about whether it is reasonable to publish staff expenses more than Â£500, as proposed by HM Treasury, on grounds of public interest. We are seeking Legal opinion before the second publication in October.
  * The data is published in CSV and Excel formats in payment date sequence.
  * From October the data will be published on the Data.Gov website, in a consistent format prescribed by HM Treasury .

**Spending data for 1 April - 11 May 2010**

On 1 April 2011 spending data over Â£500 for 1 April to 11 May 2010 was published. This completes the publication of Quarter 1 expenditure for 2010-11.

body:
**Guidance on Communities and Local Government and Government Offices spending data 2010-11**

HM Treasury (HMT) require that all central government departments should publish details of their April - September 2010 spend transaction over Â£25k by the end of October 2010, and, thereafter, publish monthly data by the 15th working day of each month.

Local Authorities will follow a similar process but will be required to publish spend over the lower Â£500 threshold from January 2011.

The CLG ALB's will each be responsible for publishing their own spend data, both on their own website and data.gov, and will publish April - September 2010 spend data at the end of October 2010, in line with other government departments.

Points to note on this report:

  * Currently listed below are the spending reports for Q1 July - September 2010.
  * Over Â£500 Transparency Spend Data is taken from SAP's General Ledger payment transactions.
  * As required by HMT, the data relates to Accounts Payable payment and credit note transactions for grants and procurement spend, recorded at the time the transaction was processed on SAP. The data excludes any subsequent journal transactions and Accounts Receivable receipts.
  * There remains however uncertainty about whether it is reasonable to publish staff expenses more than Â£500, as proposed by HMT, on grounds of public interest. We are seeking Legal opinion before the second publication in October.
  * Although the data is being circulated for review in Excel format, grouped by Directorate, the data will be published on the CLG website in CSV and Excel format in payment date sequence.
  * From October the data will be published on the Data.Gov website, in a consistent format prescribed by HMT
  * Although these figures cover the period since the new Government took office, much of the spend in this quarter relates to commitments made by the previous administration, as the figures reflect when an invoice is received from the supplier, rather than when the actual expenditure was incurred. Some ongoing expenditure is also tied into long-term contracts signed by the previous administration.

ignoreDCLG page title: Department for Communities and Local Government and Government Offices spending data January 2011
title: Spending data for DCLG and government offices January 2011
body:
**Guidance on Department for Communities and Local Government and Government Offices spending data 2010-11**

HM Treasury (HMT) requires that all central government departments should publish details of their April - September 2010 spending for transactions over Â£25,000 by the end of October 2010, and thereafter publish monthly data by the fifteenth working day of each month.

Local Authorities will follow a similar process but will publish expenditure over the lower Â£500 threshold from 31 January 2011.

The Department's arm's length bodies will each be responsible for publishing their own spending data, both on their own websites and on Data.gov, and will publish April - September 2010 spending data at the end of October 2010, in line with other government departments.

Points to note on this report:

  * Currently listed below is the spending report for January 2011.
  * Over Â£500 transparency spending data is taken from SAP's General Ledger payment transactions.
  * As required by HMT, the data relates to Accounts Payable payments and credit note transactions for grants and procurement expenditure, recorded at the time the transaction was processed on SAP. The data excludes any subsequent journal transactions and Accounts Receivable receipts.
  * Travel, subsistence and other employee transactions - These are currently published on a summarised anonomised basis. These are summarised by Expense area, then Expense Type, by day.
  * Although the data is being circulated for review in Excel format, grouped by Directorate, the data will be published on the Department website in CSV and Excel formats in payment date sequence.
  * From October the data will be published on the Data.gov website, in a consistent format prescribed by HMT.
attachment_1_title: Department for Communities and Local Government expenditure over Â£500 January 2011 (.csv format)
attachment_2_title: Department for Communities and Local Government expenditure over Â£500 January 2011
attachment_3_title: Government Offices for the regions expenditure over Â£500 January 2011 (.csv format)
attachment_4_title: Government Offices for the regions expenditure over Â£500 January 2011
attachment_5_title: Department for Communities and Local Government and Government Offices spending data January 2011: Background note

ignoreDCLG page title: DCLG Structural Reform Plan
title: Stuctural reform plan for DCLG
body: This new action plan marks a radical shift of power from Whitehall to local councils and communities that will make the Big Society part of every day life. The plan sets out a new programme for the department that will deliver radical decentralising and transparency reforms that put citizens and councils in control of their communities. It is one of the first fundamental Structural Reform Plans for making departments accountable for the implementation of the reforms set out in the Coalition agreement. (Updated June 2012)

ignoreDCLG page title: Workforce management information April 2012
title: Workforce management information data April 2012
body:
* These figures are not official statistics. They are internal workforce management information published in the interests of transparency.
  * These figures have not been reconciled centrally with any National Statistics. Where differences appear between the monthly information and National Statistics, clarifying comments will be provided. The ONS quarterly public sector employment statistics provide an official headline measure for comparing the overall size of employment in central government organisations with other sectors of the economy at the relevant quarterly reference point.
  * Some organisations may not have information available for each month, and at this stage coverage may therefore not reach 100 per cent for those organisations in scope.
  * Given the wide range of organisations covered, caution should be exercised when drawing inferences from the figures and care should be taken when making comparisons between organisations.

ignoreDCLG page title: DCLG Business Plan Quarterly Data Summary - April 2012
title: DCLG quarterly business plan summary April 2012
body:
On 4 May 2012 the Government published the Business Plan Quarterly Data Summaries.

This was published alongside Quarterly Data Summaries from departments across Whitehall to provide a quarterly snapshot on how each department is spending its budget, the results it has achieved and how it is deploying its workforce. The data summary template is the same for all departments, though many of the individual indicators are unique to the department (especially input and impact indicators).

The Quarterly Data Summaries follow commitments made at Budget 2011 and the Written Ministerial Statement on Business Plans. Their primary purpose is to make more of the management information currently held by government available to members of the public on a regular basis.

Before using this data people should ensure they take full note of the caveats noted in each Department's measurement annex. Please note that this data should not be used to make direct comparisons between departments for several reasons. This is because each department is unique and it does not make sense to compare some measures across all departments. Also, many of the measures are not directly comparable because they do not have common definitions, time periods, or data collection processes.

We intend for an annual version of this information to be formally laid in Parliament in the Annual Report and Accounts from July 2012.

The information is presented in excel format to allow the information to be presented in a re-usable format.
attachment_1_title: DCLG Business Plan Quarterly Data Summary - April 2012
attachment_2_title: Indicator measurement annex (updated April 2012)

ignoreDCLG page title: Statement of compliance with the Pre-release Access to Official Statistics Order 2008
title: Statement of compliance with the pre-release access to official statistics order 2008
body: Our statement of compliance is published in accordance with Section 9 of of the _Pre-release Access to Official Statistics Order 2008_. It sets out the arrangements we have put in place to ensure that Ministers and officials meet the criteria for being granted pre-release access to the department's official statistics prior to publication. These arrangements are designed to ensure that such access is justified, limited, controlled and publicised and complies with statutory requirements.
attachment_1_title: Statement of compliance with the Pre-release Access to Official Statistics Order 2008

ignoreDCLG page title: DCLG Open Data Strategy: April 2012 - April 2014
title: DCLG open data strategy: April 2012 to April 2014
body:
The Open Data Strategy attempts to identify how DCLG and its Arms Length Bodies can drive reform and service improvement through transparency and greater participation from citizens, communities, partner groups and small businesses. Open data is an essential part of DCLG's overarching purpose to drive forward localism and create the conditions for success.

DCLG is already at the forefront of work in government to routinely release data in more open and useful forms. This strategy highlights where DCLG intends to take action in the next two years to make open data-related improvements within the department.
ignoretype from DCLG: Corporate reports, Strategies and action plans
attachment_1_title: DCLG Open Data Strategy: April 2012 - April 2014

ignoreDCLG page title: Fire and Rescue National Framework for England
title: Fire and Rescue National Framework for England
body: The National Framework sets out the Government's expectations and requirements for fire and rescue authorities. The Government has a duty under _The Fire and Rescue Services Act 2004_ to produce the Framework and keep it current. Fire and rescue authorities must have regard to the Framework in carrying out their duties.

ignoreDCLG page title: Alcohol fund prospectus
title: Alcohol fund prospectus
summary: The documents outlines how local partnerships can apply for funding to tackle problem drinking
body:
In her third report as Government Champion for Safe and Active Communities, Baroness Newlove set out the importance of tackling the damage associated with problem drinking and announced a new Â£1 million government fund to help address this.

The attached document describes how local authorities, alongside police, schools, youth groups, the NHS, local retailers and ordinary people, could apply for a share of the fund, and sets out the selection criteria.

The closing date for applications was 1 May 2012.
attachment_1_title: Alcohol prospectus fund

ignoreDCLG page title: Guidance on community action during severe weather: The Big Society in action
title: Guidance on community action during severe weather
summary: Information for individuals and volunteer groups who want to support people affected by severe weather conditions in their local communities
body:
This document is for individuals and voluntary groups who want to get involved in helping to support people in their local communities who are affected by severe weather conditions.

This guidance challenges common misconceptions that often prevent people from volunteering (eg health and safety laws). It also contains useful resources and guidelines for those who want to volunteer.
attachment_1_title: Guidance on community action during severe weather: The Big Society in action

ignoreDCLG page title: The Troubled Families programme: Financial framework for the payment-by-results scheme for local authorities
title: The troubled families programme: financial framework
summary: Information on the Troubled Families programme payment-by-results scheme for local authorities
body:
The Troubled Families Financial Framework is a results-based funding scheme which provides details of the payment mechanism for local authorities to receive extra funding to deal with troubled families.

Aimed at local authorities, this document explains:

  * the process and criteria for drawing up the list of families who will be part of the programme
  * arrangements in regard to upfront payments
  * what local authorities would need to achieve with each family in order to claim the result-based payment.
attachment_1_title: The Troubled Families programme: Financial framework for the Troubled Families programme's payment-by-results scheme for local authorities

ignoreDCLG page title: Arms Length Bodies Reform: Managing Data Legacy
title: Arms length bodies reform: managing data legacy
body: Managing the transfer of information, records and knowledge is a key element of Arms Length Bodies reform. Ensuring that data continues to be publicly available for those bodies that are being dissolved or transferred is a priority for the Department for Communities and Local Government. This document provides information on the guidance the Department and its Arms Length Bodies will need to follow when managing data legacy.
attachment_1_title: Arms Length Bodies Reform: Managing Data Legacy

ignoreDCLG page title: Allocation of accommodation: Guidance for local housing authorities in England
title: Allocation of accommodation: guidance for local housing authorities in England
summary: Statutory guidance on social housing allocations for local authorities in England
body:
This statutory guidance on social housing allocations for local authorities in England aims to assist them to take advantage of the provisions in the Localism Act 2011. It also encourages authorities to make use of the existing flexibilities within the allocation legislation to ensure that social homes go to people who need and deserve them the most, such as hard working families and members of the Armed Forces.

The new guidance is an important part of the Government's commitment to make the social housing system more flexible and responsive.
It replaces all previous guidance on social housing allocations.
attachment_1_title: Allocation of accommodation: Guidance for local housing authorities in England

ignoreDCLG page title: Guidance Notes for completion of the Business Plan Statistical Appendix: 2009 to 2010
title: Completing the business plan statistical appendix 2009 to 2010 for early decent homes: guidance notes
body:
The purpose of the Business Plan Statistical Appendix - Early Decent Homes (BPSA-EDH) is to bring together information about the condition of your housing revenue account (HRA) stock. It draws together information relevant to the formulation of your HRA business plan and reports progress made during the last financial year.

All the information presented in the BPSA-EDH is relevant data underpinning your business planning but presented in a format to ensure consistency between local authorities (LAs). This enables readers to gain an overview of your position and will inform government office assessments. This information is used centrally to inform policy development and monitoring.
attachment_1_title: Guidance Notes for completion of the Business Plan Statistical Appendix - Early Decent Homes (BPSA-EDH): 2009/10
attachment_2_title: Business Plan Statistical Appendix - Early Decent Homes (BPSA-EDH): 2009/10 Form

ignoreDCLG page title: Build Now, Pay Later
title: Build now, pay later scheme
body:
This note provides a summary on the use of Build Now, Pay Later on the disposal of surplus public sector land following the commitment made in [Laying the Foundations: A Housing Strategy for England](http://www.communities.gov.uk/publications/housing/housingstrategy2011) to maximise the use of Build Now, Pay Later payment models where there is market demand, it represents value for money and is affordable.

It gives an overview of what Build Now, Pay Later is, the advantages it brings to landowners and developers, and the Build Now, Pay Later terms which Government Departments will ask developers to bid on when they are disposing of their land.
attachment_1_title: Build Now Pay Later

ignoreDCLG page title: Bringing Empty Homes back into use: Application guidance for Community and Voluntary Groups

body:
This guidance sets out the requirements, assessment criteria and timetable for applications where funding is sought from the empty homes community grants fund.

Applications can be made by not-for-profit community and voluntary groups who do not intend to become registered providers. Application forms and more information can be found on the grants admin website.
attachment_1_title: Bringing empty homes back into use: application guidance for community and voluntary groups

The presentation of these data will enable your authority, partners and other interested parties to gain a quick overview of your position and will inform development of the Regional Housing Strategy. Your authority will also find this appendix useful, as it brings together data items from many different housing areas in a concise and handy reference document.

ignoreDCLG page title: Local Authority Housing Statistics: 2011/12 - Guidance notes for completion
title: Completing local authority housing statistics 2011 to 2012: guidance notes
body: The purpose of this return is to collect statistical data for the evidence base to inform and monitor government strategies, policies and business objectives; responding to parliamentary questions; policy development on housing issues; evaluating the quality and value for money of public services and public bodies; benchmarking and performance monitoring by local authorities. The data are also used in other statistical products (e.g. DCLG national statistics on supply of affordable housing) and by other Government Departments.

ignoreDCLG page title: Guidance to the Mortgage Repossessions (Protection of Tenants etc) Act 2010
title: Mortgage Repossessions (Protection of Tenants etc) Act 2010: guidance
body: This guidance aims to inform lenders, landlords and tenants of their rights and responsibilities under the Mortgage Repossessions (Protection of Tenants etc) Act 2010, which aims to provide a level of protection to tenants whose landlords have let their mortgaged property without the knowledge or consent of the lender if their landlord (the mortgage-holder) falls into arrears on their mortgage payments and the lender commences repossession proceedings.
attachment_1_title: Guidance to the Mortgage Repossessions (Protection of Tenants etc) Act 2010

ignoreDCLG page title: Reinvigorating Right to Buy and One for One Replacement: Fact Sheet for Lenders
title: Reinvigorating Right to Buy: factsheet for lenders
summary: Key information for lenders about changes to the Right to Buy policy
body:
This guide sets out the key information for lenders who are currently providing mortgage finance to council or housing association tenants exercising their Right to Buy about how the new changes to the policy will affect them.

It includes details about tenant eligibility, discount repayment and the protections available for mortgage lenders.

These changes took effect from 2 April 2012.
attachment_1_title: Reinvigorating Right to Buy and one-for-one replacement: fact sheet for lenders

ignoreDCLG page title: Reinvigorating Right to Buy and One for One Replacement: Information for Local Authorities
title: Reinvigorating Right to Buy: factsheet for local authorities
summary: Key information for local authorities about changes to the Right to Buy policy
body:
This guide sets out the key information for local authorities about how the new changes to the Right to Buy policy will affect them.

ignoreDCLG page title: Openness and accountability in local pay: Draft guidance under section 40 of the Localism Act
title: Openness and accountability in local pay: draft guidance
summary: Draft guidance for local councils and fire and rescue authorities to promote openness about their employees' pay
body:
Local councils and fire and rescue authorities are required to prepare pay policy statements. These statements must set out an authorityâ€™s own policies on a range of issues relating to the pay of its workforce, particularly its senior staff (or â€˜chief officersâ€™) and its lowest paid employees.

The statements must be:

    prepared for each financial year, beginning with 2012-13
    approved by full council, or a meeting of members in the case of a fire and rescue authority
    published on relevant authoritiesâ€™ websites

This guidance is published in draft. The deadline for comments or views was 16 December 2011.
attachment_1_title: Openness and accountability in local pay: draft guidance under section 40 of the Localism Act

ignoreDCLG page title: Enterprise Zones: Application form and guidance May 2011
title: Enterprise zones: application form and guidance May 2011
body:
The Budget 2011 announced that 21 Enterprise Zones would be established in England. Eleven local enterprise partnerships were named in the Budget as the 'first wave'.

The Department published the Enterprise Zone Prospectus the day after the Budget providing information to all local enterprise partnerships about issues they need to consider in their proposals. This was followed by workshops attended by all local enterprise partnerships.

The competition to find the location of the next ten Enterprise Zones will be based on proposals that offer the best prospects to increase growth.

Applications are due by 30 June 2011 and partnerships are expected to nominate specific sites offering the best opportunity for growth. Applicants will have to show their prospective zone has genuine potential to create the new businesses they need, with positive benefits across the wider economic area.
attachment_1_title: Enterprise Zones: Application form and guidance May 2011

title: Openness and accountability in local pay: guidance
summary: Guidance for local councils and fire and rescue authorities to promote openness about their employees' pay
body:
This is the final guidance on the policy principles about accountability for pay in the Localism Act 2011.

Relevant authorities have to prepare pay policy statements. These statements must explain what an authorityâ€™s policies are on a range of issues relating to the pay of its workforce, particularly its senior staff and its lowest paid employees.

The statements must be:

prepared for each financial year, beginning with 2012-13
approved by full council, or a meeting of members in the case of a fire and rescue authority
published on relevant authoritiesâ€™ websites

If you have any queries on this guidance, please send them to:

Workforce and Pay Team
Department of Communities and Local Government
Zone 5/F5 Eland House
Bressenden Place
London
SW1E 5DU

Email: payaccountability@communities.gsi.gov.uk

body:
The Standards Board Regime has now been abolished for good â€“ freeing up councils to put in place locally drawn up codes of conduct for their elected members.

The Department for Communities and Local Government has published an illustrative text that councils can, if they choose, use as a basis for their new local code of conduct.

ignoreDCLG page title: A plain English guide to the Localism Bill - Update
title: Localism Bill: updated guidance
body:
This guide describes the main measures of the Localism Bill under four headings:

  * new freedoms and flexibilities for local government
  * new rights and powers for communities and individuals
  * reform to make the planning system more democratic and more effective
  * reform to ensure that decisions about housing are taken locally

This document is designed to give an overview only. It replaces the version published in January 2011. You can read the Bill and its explanatory notes in full, and follow its progress through parliament, on the [parliament website](http://services.parliament.uk/bills/2010-11/localism.html) (external link).

The document _Decentralisation and the Localism Bill: an essential guide_ also gives further background. It explains how the principles that underpin the Localism Bill also inform other government policies.
attachment_1_title: A plain English guide to the Localism Bill - Update

    new freedoms and flexibilities for local government

    reform to make the planning system more democratic and more effective

ignoreDCLG page title: Code for sustainable homes: Technical guide - 2010
title: Code for sustainable homes: technical guidance
body:
This technical guidance sets out the requirements for the Code for sustainable homes. It sets out the process by which a Code assessment is reached. It aims to make gaining a Code assessment as simple, transparent and rigorous as possible. It replaces the 'May 2009 Version 2' of the Code Technical Guidance. A summary of the main changes made to the Code are provided in [ _The Code for sustainable homes: Summary of the changes to the Technical Guidance - 2010_ ](http://www.communities.gov.uk/publications/planningandbuilding/codeguidesummary2010) publication.

_ [The Code for sustainable homes: Technical Guidance - frequently asked questions](http://www.communities.gov.uk/documents/planningandbuilding/xls/1970484) _ (Excel 423Kb) document provides frequently asked questions for the Code for sustainable homes Technical Guidance manual. To aid clarity, it follows the format of the Technical Guidance and is split into separate sections. The FAQs have been compiled by the Building Research Establishment, and will be reviewed quarterly.

In order to establish whether the previous or the new version of the Code applies for you, please see _ [The Code for sustainable homes:Transitional Arrangements](http://www.communities.gov.uk/documents/planningandbuilding/pdf/1766436.pdf) _ (PDF 30Kb) guidance document.

This is a priced publication available from RIBA Bookshops Mail Order, 15 Bonhill Street, London, EC2P 2EA. Order through the orders telephone line: 020 7256 7222, fax: 020 7374 2737, email: sales@ribabookshops.com or visit www.ribabookshops.com to buy online.

ignoreDCLG page title: A Guide to Determinations and Appeals (revised April 2011)
title: Building regulations determinations and appeals: guidance
body:
**This is the current version of the guide which was updated in April 2011, and replaces all previous versions**.

This guide, originally published in November 2001, has been updated in order to make it clearer to read and understand, bring it up to date and introduce forms for determination applications and appeals. It provides general guidance on the procedures contained in the Building Act 1984 for:

  * applying to the Secretary of State for Communities and Local Government for a determination in respect of the compliance of plans of proposed building work with the Building Regulations; or
  * submitting an appeal to the Secretary of State against refusal by a local authority to relax or dispense with a requirement of the Building Regulations.

The guide and the application/appeal forms can be found below.

### Fees

There is a fee payable for a determination application (with the exception for applications relating to building work solely required for disabled persons for which there is no fee). Details of the fee payable are given on the determination application form (see below).

There is no fee payable for an appeal.
attachment_1_title: Guide to determinations and appeals under the Building Act 1984, Sections 16(10)(a), 39 and 50(2) of the Building Act 1984
attachment_2_title: Determination application form
attachment_3_title: Appeal form

ignoreDCLG page title: Regeneration to enable growth: A toolkit supporting community-led regeneration
title: Community-led regeneration: toolkit
body:
Regeneration is an essential element of the Government's approach to building a strong and balanced economy.

This document explains how the Government is putting civic leaders, residents, local businesses and civil society organisations in the driving seat drive the regeneration of their area, strengthen their local economy, and improve their opportunities.

This document was originally published in January 2011 under the title _Regeneration to enable growth: What Government is doing in support of community-led regeneration_. In the year since then, Government has made considerable progress with its growth and localism agendas, which has added several new tools to the 'regeneration toolkit'.

This updated and refreshed toolkit aims to help local communities, councils, businesses and civil society organisations to navigate their way through the many tools, options, powers, flexibilities and incentives available to them as they shape plans for their area and their community.
attachment_1_title: Regeneration to enable growth: A toolkit supporting community-led regeneration

ignoreDCLG page title: Portas Pilots: Prospectus - an invitation to become a Town Team
title: Portas Pilots: prospectus for becoming a town team
body:
We are offering local partnerships the opportunity to become pilot areas to test the 'Town Team' approach and pilot some of the other ideas and recommendations set out in the Mary Portas Review. We are running a competition for local partnerships to bid for a share of Â£1 million.

The attached document describes how local partnerships can apply to become a pilot area, and sets out the selection criteria. The closing date for applications is 30 March 2012.

attachment_2_title: Portas Review Pilots Application Form

ignoreDCLG page title: Retail Markets: A good practice guide
title: Retail markets: good practice guide
body:
The Communities and Local Government Select Committee Report on retail markets recognised the need to share good practice, and recommended that the industry look in particular at how they can provide further good practice guidance and support.

This document seeks to highlight areas of good practice and signpost users to sources of more detailed information.
attachment_1_title: Retail Markets: A good practice guide

ignoreDCLG page title: Re-imagining urban spaces to help revitalise our high streets
title: Re-imagining urban spaces to help revitalise our high streets
body:
The Portas Review has highlighted the challenge that faces our high streets and town centres. In the light of changing shopping habits, high streets need to evolve to ensure they build on their strengths to offer a viable and exciting alternative to out of town and internet shopping.

Town centres and high streets have buildings and roads, but the spaces in-between are what hold them together as a place - the open spaces, squares, urban green spaces and the network of streets, pavements and pedestrian thoroughfares that knit them together. All too often, these spaces are used as no more than that - thoroughfares - and we start to forget that they can be so much more.

_Re-imagining urban spaces to help revitalise our high streets_ describes the many different ways in which these under-utilised assets can be used imaginatively to revitalise high streets and town centres - increasing high street vitality, attracting footfall and boosting local economies. It is full of inspirational case studies, and signposts some of the key documents, guidance, tools and sources of support that could help local partners re-imagine the urban spaces in their area to help revitalise their local high streets and town centres.

The guide has been developed in partnership with 19 expert organisations.
attachment_1_title: Re-imagining urban spaces to help revitalise our high streets

ignoreDCLG page title: Guidance on Students and council Tax
title: Students and council Tax: guidance
body:
Following a public consultation the Government has announced changes to the treatment of full-time students for council tax purposes. The consultation and summary of responses can be found below (see related publications).

The Council Tax (Discount Disregards) (Amendment) Order 2011/948 amends the Council tax (Discount Disregards) Order 1992 ('the Discount Disregards Order').

The purpose of the change is:

  * to allow those who have a sole or main residence in England and Wales who are undertaking a full-time course of education with an educational establishment situated in any Member State of the European Union to be treated as students for council tax purposes; and
  * to clarify the status of full-time students undertaking distance learning with an educational establishment in any Member State.

Please note that this document sets out the government's informal view of the legislation only and is not, or must not be considered, a definitive interpretation of the legislation. Definitive interpretation of any legislation is ultimately for the courts to decide.
ignoretype from DCLG: Good practice and guidance, Circulars and official letters
attachment_1_title: Guidance on Students and Council Tax

title: The housing revenue account directions 2011
body:
Following the consultation on the draft Housing Revenue Account (Accounting Practices) Directions 2011, held from 1 April to 12 May 2011, Ministers have decided to confirm the provisions contained in that document.

The new directions change or update various items of published guidance concerning the Housing Revenue Account, particularly the stock valuation guidance previously published in the _Housing Revenue Account (Accounting Practices) Direction 2007_, and brings practices in line with international financial reporting standards.

ignoreDCLG page title: Community Right to Challenge - Statutory Guidance
title: Community Right to Challenge: statutory guidance
body:
This guidance provides further explanation of the legislative framework for the Community Right to Challenge. This is contained in Part 5, Chapter 2 of the Localism Act 2011, The Community Right to Challenge (Expressions of Interest and Excluded Services) (England) Regulations 2012, and The Community Right to Challenge (Fire and Rescue Authorities and Rejection of Expressions of Interest) (England) Regulations 2012.

The Localism Act was enacted on 15 November 2011. The Community Right to Challenge was commenced on 27 June 2012.

This replaces the draft guidance published on [21 May 2012](http://www.communities.gov.uk/archived/publications/localgovernment/righttochallengestatguidance).

ignoreDCLG page title: Changes to the Energy Performance of Buildings Framework
title: Changes to the energy performance of buildings framework
body:
The documents below describe the April 2012 changes to the Energy Performance of Buildings framework.

We have taken steps to make it easier for consumers to save money on their fuel bills by:

  * introducing a new look domestic Energy Performance Certificate which is consumer friendly and easy to understand
  * requiring Domestic Energy Assessors to improve their skills and deliver a better customer service
  * opening up access to the Energy Performance Certificate register of more than seven million Energy Performance Certificates
  * amending the Regulations so the Energy Performance Certificate is provided earlier to prospective buyers and tenants, increasing the likelihood of people acting on recommendations which identify cost effective savings.
ignoretype from DCLG: Good practice and guidance, Legislation and policy

ignoreDCLG page title: Implementing self-financing for council housing
title: Implementing self-financing for council housing
summary: This document sets out reforms to the council housing finance system in England, called 'self-financing'
body:
This document sets out the rationale, methodology and financial parameters for our reforms to the council housing finance system in England â€“ 'self-financing'. It also outlines the wider policy context, including those policies that will support the successful implementation of this devolved system.

The methodology set out here builds on that which was proposed â€“ and broadly supported â€“ in the Department for Communities and Local Government's March 2010 consultation.
ignoretype from DCLG: Good practice and guidance, Reports and summaries

ignoreDCLG page title: Modelling business plans for council landlords: Local authority financial model user guide
title: Local council financial model for council housing
body:
PricewaterhouseCoopers LLP (PwC) was appointed to provide expert financial and technical support to the Department for Communities and Local Government (DCLG) team leading a project to develop a devolved system for the financing of council housing in England.

They have produced a spreadsheet model (the "Model") to assist DCLG in developing sustainable self-financing business plans for each local authority with housing stock.

The model values each local authority's council housing over a 30-year period and compares this to the amount of debt which the business currently supports. The model also quantifies and presents the national impact of these plans in aggregate.

**Please note:** It has been brought to our attention that the local authority financial model published on this website from 2 February 2011 to 10 February 2011 contained data from the draft HRA subsidy determination which for some authorities had been superceded by that published in the final determination. _All figures contained in the policy document reflected this final data and the revised version of the local authority financial model is provided below._
ignoretype from DCLG: Good practice and guidance, Reports and summaries
attachment_1_title: Modelling business plans for council landlords: Local authority financial model user guide
attachment_2_title: Local Authority Financial Model

title: Evaluating the extent of rough sleeping

body:
This guidance is intended to help local authorities, in partnership with other local agencies, to evaluate the extent of rough sleeping in their area by carrying out a count of people sleeping rough or by estimating the number of rough sleepers on a typical night in their locality.

The Department for Communities and Local Government will publish an annual figure based on this information.

The form that local authorities should use to complete the count/estimate is also provided below.

ignoreDCLG page title: Retail Markets: Management models
title: Retail markets: management models
body:
One of the key issues that has been identified as crucial to the viability and success of the retail market is the way in which the market itself is managed.

Although over half of all retail markets are operated by local councils there are a number of different models in use across the UK.

This guide provides information on, and examples of, those models, but does not advocate one form of market management over another. Its purpose is to help inform debate, so that the most appropriate management model can be identified and implemented at a local level.
ignoretype from DCLG: Good practice and guidance, Reports and summaries
attachment_1_title: Retail Markets: Management models

ignoreDCLG page title: Sanctuary Schemes for Households at Risk of Domestic Violence: Practice Guide for Agencies Developing and Delivering Sanctuary Schemes
title: Sanctuary schemes for households at risk of domestic violence: guide for agencies
body: A Sanctuary Scheme is a multi-agency victim centred initiative which aims to enable households at risk of violence to remain safely in their own homes by installing a 'Sanctuary' in the home and through the provision of support to the household. This guide highlights the transferable lessons from an evaluation of Sanctuary Schemes, and will be particularly useful for local level practitioners in developing strategies to prevent homelessness and support for households at risk of domestic violence. A summary and full research report have also been published.
attachment_1_title: Sanctuary Schemes for Households at Risk of Domestic Violence: Practice Guide for Agencies Developing and Delivering Sanctuary Schemes

ignoreDCLG page title: Parades to be proud of: Strategies to support local shops
title: Strategies to support local shops
body:
Our local parades of shops are key parts of our local areas. They affect what our local communities look and feel like, how we interact as communities and how our local economies are performing.

The Government has commissioned new research and produced this document to shine a light on these important parts of our communities. From our discussions with business owners, local authorities and interested parties, we have brought together strategies that people have used to improve parades of shops in their own areas that might be useful in other locations.

This work aims to:

  * set out the latest data on how parades of shops are faring
  * identify strategies that might help parades of shops; and
  * signpost businesses, landlords, local authorities, communities and other interested parties to useful tools
ignoretype from DCLG: Good practice and guidance, Strategies and action plans
attachment_1_title: Parades to be proud of: Strategies to support local shops

ignoreDCLG page title: Localism Bill: Enforcement package - Impact Assessment
title: Localism Bill enforcement package: impact assessment
body:
This document assesses the impact of a package of measures, including:

  * to create a power for local authorities to take enforcement action against certain breaches from the date on which they are discovered, rather than the date on which they occurred; and to increase the level of fine that can be incurred for failing to comply with Breach of Condition Notices
  * to limit the use of retrospective planning applications
  * to ensure that people who deliberately deceive the local planning authority about the nature of their intended development, or who conceal it until the window for enforcement action is past, are no longer able to profit from this practice
  * to extend the enhanced controls over advertisements that apply in London to enforcement authorities throughout the rest of England, in order to strengthen the enforcement system and improve consistency across the country
attachment_1_title: Localism Bill: enforcement package

ignoreDCLG page title: Localism Bill: Creating executive mayors in the 12 largest English cities - Impact Assessment
title: Creating executive mayors in the 12 largest English cities: impact assessment
body:
This document assesses the impact of providing that the existing leaders of the 12 specified English cities will automatically converted into 'shadow' mayors from a date specified by Order made by the Secretary of State for Communities and Local Government.

A referendum will then be held in May 2012 in each of the 12 cities in which local people will be able to vote on whether they want a mayor for their city. Should local people vote for a mayor in the referendum, the election of the city's first mayor will be held in May 2013. However, if local people vote against having a mayor in the referendum then the council will return to the leader and cabinet executive model.
attachment_1_title: Localism Bill: creating executive mayors in the 12 largest English cities - Impact assessment

ignoreDCLG page title: Localism Bill: A fairer future for social housing - Impact Assessment
title: A fairer future for social housing: impact assessment
body:
Four related policy areas are covered by this Impact Assessment: allocations, tenure, mobility and homelessness.

The document assesses the impact of:

  * reducing waiting lists by giving local authorities power to decide who qualifies to be considered for social housing while central government continues to set the rules on priority. Increasing mobility by removing most existing tenants wanting to transfer from the allocations system
  * enabling social landlords to make best use of social housing by providing greater freedom to set the terms tenancies and succession rights for new social tenants
  * Increase mobility by requiring social landlords to participate in 'home swap' (mutual exchange) schemes through which tenants can search all records of potential partners
  * better meet housing needs and reduce expenditure on temporary accommodation by ending the right that applicants for homelessness assistance have to refuse offers of private sector housing
  * allow tenants that are members of Housing Associations to benefit from home ownership incentive schemes
attachment_1_title: Localism Bill: a fairer future for social housing - Impact assessment

ignoreDCLG page title: Policy statement for Part 2 of the Localism Act 2011
title: Policy statement for part 2 of the Localism Act 2011
body:
A proposed policy statement to accompany Part 2 of the Localism Act was developed with the Local Government Association and Greater London Authority. The consultation on the proposed statement ended on 22 April 2012. As a result, the policy statement has been revised and is now available in final form.

The Localism Act provides a substantial and lasting shift in power away from central government and towards local people. The government has given public authorities more powers and freedoms to conduct their business and deliver services to the public. This includes a major reduction in the 'oversight' role of central government. Public authorities must, therefore, accept responsibility for the consequences of their actions or omissions.

Part 2 of the Localism Act is about incentivising public authorities to comply with European law, in order to avoid any financial sanctions in the first place. The policy statement sets out a fair, proportionate and reasonable approach for the use of Part 2.
attachment_1_title: Policy statement for Part 2 of the Localism Act 2011
attachment_2_title: Part 2 of the Localism Act 2011 - Questions and answers

The NPPF is a key part of the governmentâ€™s reforms to make the planning system less complex and more accessible. It vastly simplifies the number of policy pages about planning.

The framework acts as guidance for local planning authorities and decision-takers, both in drawing up plans and making decisions about planning applications.

body:
Planning Policy Statement 10 (PPS10) sets out the government's policy to be taken into account by waste planning authorities and forms part of the national waste management plan for the UK.

This replaces _Planning Policy Guidance 10: Planning and Waste Management_ (PPG10) published in 1999 and an earlier edition of PPS10 published on 21 July 2005.

ignoreDCLG page title: Planning policy for traveller sites
title: Planning policy for traveller sites
body:
The government has published its new planning policy for traveller sites. This policy comes into effect at the same time as the [National Planning Policy Framework](http://www.communities.gov.uk/planningandbuilding/planningsystem/planningpolicy/planningpolicyframework/). The new planning policy for traveller sites should be read in conjunction with the National Planning Policy Framework.

_Circular 01/06: Planning for Gypsy and traveller Caravan Sites_ and _Circular 04/07: Planning for Travelling Showpeople_ will be cancelled when the new policy comes into force.
ignoretype from DCLG: Legislation and policy, Good practice and guidance
attachment_1_title: Planning policy for traveller sites

ignoreDCLG page title: The general consents under section 25 of the Local Government Act 1988 (Local Authority assistance for privately let housing) 2010
title: General consents for privately let housing
body:
The consents set out those situations (other than those prescribed in the primary legislation) where the consent of the Secretary of State for Communities and Local Government is not needed for local authorities to provide financial support for privately let housing accommodation.

**Note:** These consents issued in December 2010 were updated in July 2011 to take account of changes to legislation given effect by the Housing and Regeneration Act 2008 (Registration of Local Authorities) Order 2010. The only changes are new paragraphs B2(g) and D6(e).

They were further amended in January 2012 when paragraphs A2(d)(i) and B2(e)(i) were slightly modified to be less restrictive.
ignoretype from DCLG: Legislation and policy, Reports and summaries
attachment_1_title: The general consents under section 25 of the Local Government Act 1988 (Local Authority assistance for privately let housing) 2010

title: Self-financing for council housing: planning the transition
summary: This document updates the policy arrangements set out in 'Implementing self-financing for council housing' published on 1 February 2011
body:
The purpose of the document is to:

provide local authorities with the detailed information they need to prepare for and achieve a successful transition to self-financing for council housing
provide an update on the wider policy and accounting context within which self-financing will operate

The publication also contains:

a summary which could be used to explain the reforms to tenants or other interested groups at annex A
updated demolitions guidance at annex B

attachment_2_title: The housing revenue account and self-financing determinations

ignoreDCLG page title: How change of use is handled in the planning system - tell us what you think: Issues paper
title: Change of land use in the planning system: issues paper
body:
As part of the Plan for Growth, the government announced that there would be a review of how change of use is handled in the planning system. The key aim of this review is to look at the scope for further liberalisation and how we might remove the barriers to change of use to help facilitate growth.

This paper is the first stage of that review and is intended to promote discussion and serve as an invitation to interested parties to submit evidence of any issues with the operation of the current system and areas for possible change.
ignoretype from DCLG: Legislation and policy, Reports and summaries
attachment_1_title: How change of use is handled in the planning system - tell us what you think: Issues paper

ignoreDCLG page title: An introduction to neighbourhood planning
title: Neighbourhood planning: an introduction
body:
This leaflet provides an easy-to-read introduction to neighbourhood planning being introduced by the government. This is a new way for communities to decide the future of the places where they live and work.

This leaflet explains what neighbourhood planning is, why it matters and how it will work and provides information about the sources of advice and support for communities interested in doing neighbourhood planning.
ignoretype from DCLG: Legislation and policy, Reports and summaries

ignoreDCLG page title: Business rates retention scheme: The central and local shares of business rates - A Statement of Intent
title: Business rates retention scheme: central and local shares of business rates: statement
body:
The statement of intent sets out how locally collected business rates will be shared between central and local government. It details the grants from central government to local authorities that will be included within the rates retention scheme. It states that government does not intend to reset the system until 2020 at the earliest, except in exceptional circumstances.

**Please note:** An update to the statement of intent on the central and local shares of business rates (at Annex A, footnote 6) was made on 13 June 2012.
ignoretype from DCLG: Legislation and policy, Strategies and action plans

ignoreDCLG page title: Localising support for council tax: A statement of intent on information sharing and powers to tackle fraud
title: Localising support for Council Tax: information sharing and powers to tackle fraud
body:
Localising Council Tax support is part of a wider set of reforms to the welfare system. This statement of intent sets out:

  * the purposes relating to Council Tax for which regulations will permit information held by Her Majesty's Revenue and Customs to be supplied to billing authorities in England. It also sets out the purposes for which information may be supplied by the Department for Work and Pensions to billing authorities under existing powers in the Welfare Reform Act 2012
  * the necessary powers, offences and penalties, to allow local authorities to investigate and tackle potential fraudulent Council Tax support claims
ignoretype from DCLG: Legislation and policy, Strategies and action plans

ignoreDCLG page title: Localising support for council tax: Explanatory Note on Draft Regulations
title: Localising support for Council Tax: explanatory note on draft regulations
body:
Localising Council Tax support is part of a wider set of reforms to the welfare system. The explanatory note sets out:

  * the government's approach in publishing these regulations in draft form. This is intended to give authorities and interested parties the opportunity to make any comments or ask questions on the process and the draft regulations, to ensure that the final versions will enable local authorities to implement the prescribed requirements or default scheme smoothly.
  * the technical approaches - for example, how the draft regulations treat the new Universal Credit benefit and certain provisions that will, in future, be covered by existing regulations under the Local Government Finance Act 1992.
ignoretype from DCLG: Legislation and policy, Strategies and action plans

ignoreDCLG page title: Apportionment of Rents (leasehold houses)/Rentcharges (freehold houses)
title: Apportionment of rents and rentcharges
summary: Leaflet explaining how owners of property can legally separate their share of a ground rent or rentcharge from other properties
body:
This document explains how the owner of a:

freehold house affected by a rentcharge (sometimes known as a chief rent) which also affects houses owned by other people
leasehold house on which they pay a ground rent, which is also payable on other neighbouring properties

can legally separate (apportion) their share of the rent from the other properties. Application forms for both processes are also available to download below.
attachment_1_title: Apportionment of rents (leasehold houses)/rentcharges (freehold houses)
attachment_2_title: Application for the apportionment of a ground rent â€“ leasehold land in different ownership
attachment_3_title: Application for the apportionment of a rentcharge â€“ freehold land in different ownership

ignoreDCLG page title: Redemption of Rentcharges on freehold houses
title: Redemption of rentcharges on freehold houses
summary: This leaflet explains how an owner of a freehold house may be able to redeem a rentcharge
body:
The owner of a freehold house paying a rentcharge (sometimes known as a chief rent) may be able to redeem the rentcharge by paying a single lump sum (if the rentcharge is a type that is redeemable under the provisions of the Rentcharges Act 1977).

The application form and guidance notes to be used when seeking to redeem a rentcharge payable on a freehold house is available to download below.
attachment_1_title: Redemption of rentcharges on freehold houses
attachment_2_title: Application form for a redemption certificate in respect of a rentcharge on freehold house

ignoreDCLG page title: Proposed Programme of Research and Analysis for 2011-12
title: Proposed DCLG research and analysis for 2011 to 2012
summary: DCLG's proposed programme of research and analysis for 2011 to 2012
body:
This is a notice of the Department for Communities and Local Government's (DCLG) intention to proceed with a proposed programme of research for 2011-12.

The programme will cover core policy areas of housing, planning, localism and decentralisation, economic growth and local economic development, fire and resilience, sustainable buildings and climate change.

This year there is a different process for bidding for external research contracts. DCLG will not be seeking expressions of interest for individual projects.  Instead, in accordance with the new transparency agenda, (and to give all organisations the chance to submit a competitive tender for any of the projects), all our projects will be advertised, in open competition, on the Government's 'Contracts Finder' website.
attachment_1_title: Proposed Programme of Research and Analysis for 2011-12

ignoreDCLG page title: All-Party Inquiry into Antisemitism: Government response - Three years on progress report
title: All-party inquiry into antisemitism: progress report
body:
In September 2006, the all-party Parliamentary inquiry into antisemitism published a comprehensive report about the sources of contemporary antisemitism.

In May 2008 the previous government published a progress report on the 35 recommendations made by the all-party inquiry into antisemitism.

This 3-year update is based on the 5 themes in the original inquiry report:

* antisemitic incidents
* antisemitic discourse
* sources of contemporary antisemitism
* antisemitism on campus
* addressing antisemitism

This is a priced publication available from TSO (The Stationery Office), PO Box 29, Norwich NR3 1GN. Order through the Parliamentary Hotline (Lo-call): 08457 023 474, fax: 0870 600 5533, textphone 0870 240 3701, email: book.orders@tso.co.uk or visit www.tsoshop.co.uk to buy online.
attachment_1_title: All-Party Inquiry into Antisemitism: Government Response - Three Years on Progress Report

ignoreDCLG page title: Building Safe, Active Communities: Strong foundations by local people
title: Building safe, active communities: strong foundations by local people
summary: Third report by Baroness Newlove, the government's Champion for Active, Safer Communities
body:
Baroness Newlove was appointed as the governmentâ€™s Champion for Active, Safer Communities in October 2010. Since then she has worked with communities across the country to find out what grassroots activists want and need.

This is her third report. It is a manual for communities that brings together new ideas that have been proven to work and case studies from different areas. It highlights resources that can provide support to communities that want to do more.
attachment_1_title: Building safe, active communities: strong foundations by local people

ignoreDCLG page title: Listening to Troubled Families: A report by Louise Casey CB
title: Listening to troubled families
body:
Louise Casey, head of the troubled families programme, interviewed 16 troubled families for this report that starkly describes the problems families face.

The primary purpose of carrying out the interviews was to listen directly to families about their lives, the problems they have experienced and caused and to begin to understand the sort of help that will enable them to really change.
attachment_1_title: Listening to Troubled Families: A report by Louise Casey CB

body:
