*  the costs of participatory budgeting processes
* what works in the operation of participatory processes
* the results/outcomes achieved by the process
attachment_1_title: Communities in the driving seat: a study of Participatory Budgeting in England - Final report

ignoreDCLG page title: Baroness Newlove: Our vision for safe and active communities - Government Progress Update
title: Safe and active communities: government progress update
body:
In March 2011, Baroness Newlove, the government's Champion for Active Safer Communities, published _Our vision for safe and active communities_. This called for a change of culture so neighbourhoods no longer see crime, antisocial behaviour and disorder as 'someone else's problem'.

This report provides an update on the government's progress in achieving Baroness Newlove's challenges to action.
attachment_1_title: Baroness Newlove: Our vision for safe and active communities - Government Progress Update

ignoreDCLG page title: Sustainable Communities Act 2007: Decisions on proposals submitted following the 2008 invitation
title: Sustainable Communities Act 2007: decisions on local councils' proposals to improve local areas
body:
In October 2009, the then Secretary of State for Communities and Local Government issued an invitation to local authorities under the Sustainable Communities Act to submit proposals which they believed would improve the social, economic and environmental well-being of their local area.

This document gives the secretary of state's decisions on over 300 separate requests contained within the 199 proposals short-listed by the Local Government Association in December 2009.
attachment_1_title: Sustainable Communities Act 2007: Decisions on proposals submitted following the 2008 invitation

ignoreDCLG page title: The training and development of Muslim Faith Leaders: Current practice and future possibilities
title: Muslim faith leaders: training and development now and in the future
body:
This independent report was commissioned under the last government in response to requests from Muslim communities.

This report's main aim was to explore and evaluate the current training provisions for British Muslim faith leaders and to identify any gaps in this training.

This final report includes a number of key messages and action points for educational institutions, Muslim community organisations and government.

Please note:

* **this project was commissioned under the previous administration**

* **the findings and recommendations are those of the authors and do not necessarily represent those of the Department for Communities and Local Government**
attachment_1_title: The training and development of Muslim Faith Leaders: Current practice and future possibilities

ignoreDCLG page title: Arm's length bodies' spending data 2009-10
title: DCLG's arm's length bodies' spending 2009 to 2010
body:
### Payments to suppliers

The Department of Communities and Local Government (DCLG) is fully committed to the government's transparency agenda. In support of this we are pleased to publish data confirming our arm's length bodies expenditure with suppliers for year 6 April 2009 to 5 April 2010. This data is provided in advance of our wider commitment to publish data via HM Treasury for publication on the data.gov.uk website later in the year. Our non-departmental public bodies, agencies and executive agencies are making their own arrangements to publish data for the same period later this year.

The attached report is freely re-usable under the same terms as data.gov.uk.

If you have any enquiries relating to any of the data provided, please send an email to [procurementhelp@communities.gsi.gov.uk](mailto:procurementhelp@communities.gsi.gov.uk). Our staff will aim to provide a response to your enquiry within 10 working days. While we aim to be as transparent as we can, there may be some cases where we will need to withhold information that could be regarded as sensitive for commercial or security reasons, or to protect personal privacy.

### Future developments

Publication of this information forms the first part of our ongoing commitment to be open and transparent with our expenditure information. The DCLG will be publishing further information detailing our first quarter spend for 2010-11 with third-party suppliers by the end of September 2010.
attachment_1_title: Communities and Local Government group: Procurement expenditure 2009-10 - covering note

ignoreDCLG page title: The audit and inspection of local authorities: Memorandum from the Department for Communities and Local Government
title: Audit and inspection of local authorities
body:
On 25 June 2010, the government instructed the Audit Commission and 5 other inspectorates to stop comprehensive area assessments. On 13 August 2010, the government announced plans to disband the Audit Commission. These decisions are part of a fundamental shift in power away from central government to councils and communities, overturning decades of increasing central government control.

This memorandum outlines how the government is taking forward the establishment of a new, more localist, audit regime for local public bodies, and the underlying principles on which the government believes any such regime should be based.
attachment_1_title: The audit and inspection of local authorities: Memorandum from the Department for Communities and Local Government

ignoreDCLG page title: Departmental Adaptation Plan: Update May 2011
title: DCLG adaptation plan: May 2011 update
body:
This update to the Department for Communities and Local Government's (DCLG) adaptation plan summarises the department's policies and priorities in relation to the climate change adaptation agenda.

It provides examples of positive local action, the steps being taken to build skills and knowledge of climate change within DCLG, and the work being undertaken to assess the risks to the departmental estate.
attachment_1_title: Departmental Adaptation Plan: Update May 2011

ignoreDCLG page title: Fourth Statement of New Regulation
title: Fourth statement of new regulation of 'one-in, one-outâ€™ regime
body:
The fourth statement of new regulation is a forward look of all regulations in scope of government's 'one-in, one-out' regime (including measures which are deregulatory) that are scheduled to come into force between 1 July and 31 December 2012.

This is published every 6 months to give businesses an indication of when regulations affecting them will be coming into effect.

The headline figures show:

  * the measures we are introducing this year will reduce burdens on businesses by an estimated Â£0.3 million per year.

The statement of new regulation, combined with other measures that form part of the government's strategy for reducing regulation, is designed to reduce Whitehall's tendency to regulate and give businesses clarity about all new regulations being introduced. It provides an overview of the net costs and benefits to business and civil society organisations. The statement is published every 6 months to give businesses an indication of when regulations affecting them will be coming into effect.
attachment_1_title: Fourth Statement of New Regulation

title: DCLG's progress against the Public Accounts Committee's recommendations 2011
body:
The Department for Communities and Local Government is responsible for implementing most of the recommendations and conclusions in Treasury minutes, encompassing government responses to Public Accounts Committee reports, published during 2010-11.

This report sets out the committee's recommendations and conclusions and government responses to Public Accounts Committee reports, published during 2010-11.

ignoreDCLG page title: The Coalition: Our Programme for Government on Communities and Local Government
title: Coalition programme for government on communities and local government
body:
This document sets out the government's response to the comments made by the public on _The Coalition: Our Programme for Government_ and, specifically, the communities and local government section of the coalition agreement.

We are grateful to 352 members of the public who took time to comment on this section of the agreement. It is not possible to respond to every comment. Therefore this document seeks to respond to the issues that raised the greatest level of comments and reflects the policies as they apply in England only.
attachment_1_title: The Coalition: Our Programme for Government on Communities and Local Government

ignoreDCLG page title: The English Indices of Deprivation 2010: Guidance document
title: English indices of deprivation 2010: guidance
body:
The purpose of the English indices of deprivation 2010 is to identify small areas of England which are experiencing multiple aspects of deprivation. It replaces the indices of deprivation 2007 as the official measure of deprivation in England.

This guidance document provides key information on the indices of deprivation 2010.
attachment_1_title: English Indices of Deprivation 2010: Guidance document

body:
The third statement of new regulation is a forward look of all regulations in scope of governmentâ€™s â€˜one-in, one-outâ€™ regime (including measures which are deregulatory) being introduced by the Department for Communities and Local Government which will have an impact on businesses.

Theyâ€™re scheduled to come into force between 1 January 2012 and 30 June 2012. The headline figures show that the measures weâ€™re introducing this year will reduce burdens on businesses by an estimated Â£230,000 a year.

ignoreDCLG page title: Update on the Third Statement of New Regulation
title: Third statement of new regulation of 'one-in, one-outâ€™ regime: update
body:
The Department for Communities and Local Government's third statement of new regulation looked at all regulations in scope of the government's 'one-in, one-out' regime (including measures which are deregulatory) that came into force between 1 January and 30 June 2012. This update provides more detail on the progress of each measure that was included in the third statement of new regulation.

The statement of new regulation, combined with other measures that form part of the government's strategy for reducing regulation, is designed to reduce Whitehall's tendency to regulate and give businesses clarity about all new regulations being introduced. It provides an overview of the net costs and benefits to business and civil society organisations. The statement is published every 6 months to give businesses an indication of when regulations affecting them will be coming into effect.
attachment_1_title: Update on the Third Statement of New Regulation

title: Fire futures report: chairs' foreword
body: This is the chairs' foreword to the fire futures report on options for the future provision of fire and rescue in England.
attachment_1_title: Fire Futures - Chairs' Foreword: A Series of options for the future of fire and rescue provision in England.

ignoreDCLG page title: Fire Futures Report Government Response
title: Fire futures report: government response
summary: Government response to the fire futures report on the reform of fire and rescue services
body:
This is the fire futures government response.

It outlines how the government intends to take forward with the sector the public service reform agenda in the context of fire and rescue services at the local level and in terms of national resilience.
attachment_1_title: Fire Futures report: government response

ignoreDCLG page title: Fire Futures: Role of the Fire and Rescue Service (Delivery Models) Report
title: Fire futures report: delivery models
body: This report looks at the additional powers and responsibilities required to overcome barriers faced by the fire and rescue service in delivering service and options for closer working with other emergency services.
attachment_1_title: Fire Futures - Role of the Fire and Rescue Service (Delivery Models) Report

ignoreDCLG page title: Fire Futures: National Interests Workstream - Decentralisation in the fire sector - Empowering and protecting the citizen
title: Fire futures report: empowering and protecting the citizen
body: This report looks at the respective roles of the fire and rescue service and government in national resilience, the built environment, improved knowledge management and decentralisation.
attachment_1_title: Fire Futures - National Interests Workstream - Decentralisation in the fire sector - Empowering and protecting the citizen

ignoreDCLG page title: The Fire Service College Pre-Market Engagement on Future Options
title: Fire Service College: pre-market engagement on future options
body: The government announced its intention to explore options for a new ownership, operational and governance model for the Fire Service College. To explore options and gauge market interest the Department for Communities and Local Government is undertaking a short phase of pre-market engagement. This document invites interested parties to offer clear views on the future of the college to allow the department to assess the reaction of the market to the overarching aim of delivering a new model for the Fire Service College.
attachment_1_title: Fire Servce College Pre-market engagement of future options

ignoreDCLG page title: Grant for future control room services: Summary 'National Picture' of fire and rescue authority improvement plans
title: Grant for future control room services: summary national picture of fire and rescue authority improvement plans
summary: The document provides a summary 'national picture' of the improvement plans proposed by the fire and rescue authorities in England
body:
The document provides a summary 'national picture' of the improvement plans proposed by the fire and rescue authorities in England, in response to the Department for Communities and Local Government invitation to them to submit bids for the future controls room services funding.

Based on information supplied by the fire and rescue authorities, the document summarises the planned improvements, delivery timescales and projected savings. The document shows a build-up of resilience across the country resulting from specific improvements at a local level in fire and rescue control services, including additional benefits resulting from partnering with other fire and rescue authorities.
attachment_1_title: Grant for future control room services: summary 'national picture' of fire and rescue authority improvement plans

body: This document provides the high-level summaries of information supplied by fire and rescue authorities in England in their bid for grant funding to support the upgrading and rationalisation of control services.
attachment_1_title: Future control room services scheme: fire and rescue authorities' summaries

The document is aimed at users of this data both in fire and rescue authorities and elsewhere.

ignoreDCLG page title: Update of response time loss relationships for the Fire Service Emergency Cover toolkit - Fire Research Report 3/2010
title: Relationship between response times to fires and loss of life and property: fire service emergency cover toolkit
body:
The fire service emergency cover toolkit uses formulae that relate response times to the loss of life and property in fires and special service incidents. These relationships were deveolped, mostly, using fire and incident data.

This draft report provides a summary of analysis completed to review and update response time-loss relationships used in the fires safety emergencey cover toolkit.
attachment_1_title: Update of response time loss relationships for the Fire Service Emergency Cover toolkit - Fire research Report 3/2010

ignoreDCLG page title: Accelerating the release of public sector land
title: Accelerating the release of public sector land
body:
This summary report provides an update following the announcement by the Housing Minister in June 2011 of government plans to accelerate the release of public sector land to deliver up to 100,000 homes within the Comprehensive Spending Review period, and support economic growth.

It gives an overview of the work that has already been done, how we are and will continue to support and facilitate the accelerated release of public land, and proposals for taking the next phase of work forward.
attachment_1_title: Accelerating the release of public sector land: Update, overview and next steps

ignoreDCLG page title: English housing survey - Technical Advice Notes
title: English housing survey: technical advice
body:
These documents are advice notes to support users of the English housing survey findings and data sets. They provide detailed information about how the survey data is collected and quality assured, the sampling and weighting methodology, a glossary of terms and how some of the important measures for analysis are derived.

_There will be periodic updates to reflect any changes to the survey methods._

  * Survey methods, sampling and weighting: Revisions for 2010-11 Survey **(Update)
**(ISBN: 978 1 4098 3552 3)
  * Housing and neighbourhood conditions
(ISBN: 978 1 4098 2698 9)
  * Household derived indicators: Revisions for 2010-11 Survey **(Update)
**(ISBN: 978 1 4098 3507 3)
  * Energy efficiency and energy improvements: Revisions for 2010-11 Survey **(Update)
**(ISBN: 978 1 4098 3506 6)
  * Glossary
(ISBN: 978 1 4098 2714 6)
  * Market value survey
(ISBN: 978 1 4098 2700 9)
  * Data quality
(ISBN: 978 1 4098 2958 4)

The deadline for applications was 12 July 2011.

ignoreDCLG page title: National Evaluation of the Handyperson Programme
title: National evaluation of the handyperson programme
summary: Independent evaluation by University of York of the Department for Communities and Local Government (DCLG) handyperson programme
body:
This is the final report of an independent evaluation of the DCLG handyperson programme.

Undertaken by the University of York, the evaluation reports on value for money and the success of the programme in meeting service usersâ€™ needs.

The findings and recommendations in this report are those of the consultant authors and do not necessarily represent the views or proposed policies of DCLG.
attachment_1_title: National evaluation of the handyperson programme

ignoreDCLG page title: Lifetime Neighbourhoods
title: Lifetime neighbourhoods
summary: Independent research report by the Centre for Housing Policy at York University on lifetime neighbourhoods
body:
This report, commissioned by the Department for Communities and Local Government, brings together existing writings and research plus practice examples of lifetime neighbourhoods. Lifetime neighbourhoods are places designed to be inclusive regardless of age or disability.

The report contributes to the governmentâ€™s commitment to help older people live independently. It should help to prompt thinking around how, for example, ageing, design, housing, transport, participation and green spaces can be linked when creating lifetime neighbourhoods.
attachment_1_title: Lifetime neighbourhoods

ignoreDCLG page title: Lifetime Neighbourhoods: Practice Examples - Summary Resource 246
title: Lifetime neighbourhoods: practice examples
body:
Recognising the importance of neighbourhood as a determinant of well-being in later life and its crucial role in supporting older people's independence, the Department for Communities and Local Government commissioned the Centre for Housing Policy at the University of York to explore and develop the idea of a 'lifetime neighbourhood', and search out and present examples of how the idea has been taken forward in different parts of the country.

This summary describes the key elements that make up a lifetime neighbourhood, and sets out how individual residents, communities, local government, practitioners, councillors, the voluntary sector and the private sector can become involved and contribute to the development of lifetime neighbourhoods.
attachment_1_title: Lifetime Neighbourhoods: Practice Examples - Summary Resource 246

ignoreDCLG page title: Park homes: Government response to the Select Committee first report of session 2012-13
title: Park homes: government response to the Communities and Local Government Select Committee report
body:
This paper sets out the government's response to the issues raised by the Communities and Local Government Select Committee in their [report on park homes](http://www.publications.parliament.uk/pa/cm201213/cmselect/cmcomloc/177/17702.htm).

This is a priced publication available from TSO (The Stationery Office), PO Box 29, Norwich NR3 1GN. Order through the Parliamentary Hotline (Lo-call): 08457 023 474, fax: 0870 600 5533, textphone 0870 240 3701, email: book.orders@tso.co.uk or visit www.tsoshop.co.uk to buy online.
attachment_1_title: Park homes: Government response to the House of Commons Communities and Local Government Select Committee first report of session 2012-13

ignoreDCLG page title: Accelerating the release of surplus public sector land: Progress report one year on
title: Accelerating the release of surplus public sector land: progress report
body:
This report sets out the progress made in the past year to accelerate the release of surplus public land to support housing. It also describes the support mechanisms that have been put in place to help departments dispose of land and the next steps for the programme in the coming year.

As set out in Budget 2012 sufficient land has been identified to meet the government's ambition to dispose of land with the capacity to build over 100,000 homes by April 2015.
attachment_1_title: Accelerating the release of surplus public sector land: Progress report one year on

ignoreDCLG page title: The Housing Revenue Account Self-financing Determinations
title: The housing revenue account self-financing determinations
summary: The final 5 determinations for implementing self-financing for council housing
body:
Under section 173 of the Localism Act 2011, the secretary of state is required to consult representatives of local government and each affected local authority before making determinations to implement self-financing for council housing. This consultation was published on 21 November 2011, and also included amendments to the:

* 2011-12 housing revenue account subsidy determination
* 2011-12 item 8 determinations
* item 8 determinations that will apply from April 2012

title: Review of social housing regulation
summary: Recommendations of the review of the role of the Tenant Services Authority (TSA)
body:
In June 2010, Grant Shapps, Minister for Housing, announced a review of the role and purpose of the TSA and the framework for social housing regulation.

This report looks at the context for the review, sets out its main conclusions and outlines the implications for the organisations and individuals affected.

ignoreDCLG page title: Vision to end rough sleeping: No Second Night Out nationwide
title: Vision to end rough sleeping
summary: First report from ministerial working group to tackle homelessness
body:
The Ministerial Working Group on Homelessness brings together 8 government departments to tackle the complex causes of homelessness - not only housing but also health, work and training.

The ministerial working group has been working with local government and voluntary sector partners to produce its first report, focused on ending rough sleeping.

This report, â€˜No Second Night Out nationwideâ€™, sets out 6 joint commitments. Together, they mean we will work across government to give local people the tools to tackle rough sleeping and put an end to second nights out on the street.
attachment_1_title: Vision to end rough sleeping: No Second Night Out nationwide

ignoreDCLG page title: Accountability: Adapting to decentralisation
title: Accountability: adapting to decentralisation
summary: This report examines how accounting officers will both drive the government's localism agenda and continue to account to Parliament for the use of public money
body:
Where decentralised delivery arrangements are used, the report recommends that accounting officers should be responsible for ensuring that there is a robust local accountability system in place and that accounting officers should publish statements setting out the accountability systems for the major decentralised funding streams that they responsible for.

The report includes example accountability system statements for local government and the police.

This version was provided to the Public Accounts Committee to inform the hearing on 14 September 2011.
attachment_1_title: Accountability: adapting to decentralisation

body:
This document sets out the current funding systems, legislation and guidance which forms the system at present, and signposts changes which are expected to be made during the year.

This system covers the core accountability system for local authorities, which is concerned with issues such as their financial management and democratic accountability.

Annex B sets out the arrangements in place for fire and rescue authorities.
attachment_1_title: Accountability system statement for local government

ignoreDCLG page title: Future changes to the Building Regulations - next steps
title: Building regulations: future changes
body:
At the end of July 2010 external partners were invited to submit their ideas and evidence on ways to improve the Building Regulations, on reducing the regulatory burdens and on ways to deliver even better levels of compliance.

Several hundred responses were received providing helpful and valuable information which we have used in developing the programme. The main theme to emerge has been that partners believe the regime is generally fit-for-purpose, but that there are things that can be improved.

The plan now is to take forward a programme of work to examine a number of areas and to develop detailed proposals for consultation. This programme will have a particular focus on deregulation and streamlining of the technical and procedural aspects of the regulations.
attachment_1_title: Future changes to the Building Regulations - next steps

ignoreDCLG page title: Forecasting Aggregates Demand: a technical summary
title: Forecasting aggregates demand: technical summary
body:
This technical paper summaries the Department for Communities and Local Government's (DCLG) approach to forecasting the demand for aggregates. This report explains the modelling and forecasting process undertaken in preparing the national and regional guidelines for the provision of aggregates and the subsequent monitoring of these guidelines (as presented in the annual monitoring reports).

**Note:** This publication was issued by our former department, the Office of the Deputy Prime Minister (ODPM). ODPM became DCLG on 5 May 2006.
attachment_1_title: Forecasting Aggregates Demand: a technical summary

ignoreDCLG page title: Progress report by the ministerial working group on tackling inequalities experienced by Gypsies and travellers
title: Reducing inequalities for gypsies and travellers: progress report
body:
Gypsies and travellers experience, and are being held back by, some of the worst outcomes of any group across a wide range of social indicators. In November 2010, the Secretary of State for Communities and Local Government set up a ministerial working group to tackle these issues, bringing together ministers from 7 government departments.

This progress report includes 28 commitments from across government that will help mainstream services work more effectively with the gypsy and traveller communities.
attachment_1_title: Progress report by the ministerial working group on tackling inequalities experienced by Gypsies and travellers

ignoreDCLG page title: Zero carbon homes: Impact assessment
title: Zero carbon homes: impact assessment
body:
This impact assessment sets out the evidence and argument for the implementation of a new definition of zero carbon homes.

From 2016, developers will be required to deal with all emissions from new build homes that fall under the scope of building regulations. A specified portion of this will have to be dealt with on-site through energy efficiency measures such as insulation and onsite renewables such as solar panels. The remaining emissions can be dealt with through offsite measures, the mechanism for which has yet to be decided.
attachment_1_title: Zero carbon homes: Impact assessment

ignoreDCLG page title: National Evaluation of the Local Enterprise Growth Initiative Programme - Final report
title: National evaluation of the local enterprise growth initiative
body: The independent evaluation of the local enterprise growth initiative programme (LEGI) programme provides an overall analysis on the impact of the fund and the implications for future enterprise policy and interventions.
attachment_1_title: National Evaluation of the Local Enterprise Growth Initiative Programme - Final report
attachment_2_title: National Evaluation of the Local Enterprise Growth Initiative Programme - Appendices

ignoreDCLG page title: Portas Pilots Round 2: Prospectus - an invitation to become a Town Team
title: Portas Pilots round 2: prospectus
body:
We are offering local partnerships in England the opportunity to become pilot areas to test the 'town team' approach and pilot some of the other ideas and recommendations set out in the Mary Portas review.

The attached document describes how local partnerships could apply to become a pilot area, and sets out the selection criteria. The closing date for applications was 30 June 2012.
attachment_1_title: Portas Pilots Round 2: Prospectus - an invitation to become a Town Team

ignoreDCLG page title: The Portas Review: An independent review into the future of our high streets
title: The Portas review: the future of our high streets
body:
On 17 May 2011 the Prime Minister announced that he had asked Mary Portas, leading retail marketing consultant, to undertake a review of the English high street.

The purpose of the Portas review was to identify what the government, local authorities, businesses and others can do together to promote the development of new models of prosperous and diverse high streets. It forms part of the government's work on the growth agenda.
attachment_1_title: The Portas Review: An independent review into the future of our high streets

ignoreDCLG page title: Supporting retail markets: Executive summary
title: Supporting retail markets: executive summary
body:
Many traditional retail markets have seen a decline in recent years even though the successful retail market can bring real economic, social and environmental benefits to local communities.

In order to ensure that such benefits were fully realised, the government tapped into the knowledge and expertise of the markets industry to identify the issues that would support retail markets going forward.
attachment_1_title: Supporting retail markets: Executive summary

ignoreDCLG page title: A Review of Coalfields Regeneration - Government response to recommendations
title: Coalfields regeneration: government response
body: This government response to the Coalfields Regeneration Review Board report was presented to Michael Clapham by the Department for Communities and Local Government ministers on 10 March 2011.
attachment_1_title: A Review of Coalfields Regeneration - Government response to recommendations

ignoreDCLG page title: A Review of Coalfields Regeneration
title: Coalfields regeneration review
body:
This report was produced by the Coalfields Regeneration Review Board, led by Michael Clapham. The review considered how government can best support regeneration of the former mining communities. It looked at:

* the case for coalfields intervention
* national and local government engagement
* the structure and effectiveness of the entire coalfields programmes
* co-ordination and local arrangements

The report contains recommendations on the future of government intervention in the coalfields.
attachment_1_title: A Review of Coalfields Regeneration

ignoreDCLG page title: England's Smaller Seaside Towns: A benchmarking study
title: England's smaller seaside towns: benchmarking study
body:
This report provides an information base on England's smaller seaside towns. It presents a range of statistical evidence on socio-economic conditions and compares the figures with regional, rural and English averages and with the averages for larger seaside towns.

The report is a direct counterpart to a benchmarking study of England's larger seaside towns, published in 2008.

The report focuses on 37 smaller 'seaside towns' (or resorts) rather than all smaller places around the coast. All these towns have a population below 10,000, which qualifies them as 'rural' settlements on official definitions.
attachment_1_title: England's Smaller Seaside Towns: A benchmarking study

ignoreDCLG page title: Supporting Local Growth
title: Supporting local growth
body:
The government's aim is to promote strong, sustainable and balanced growth in every part of the country, and a year ago it set out its approach as to how it would do so.

One year on, the _Supporting Local Growth_ report highlights the progress the government has made with the introduction of local enterprise partnerships, Enterprise Zones, a Regional Growth Fund and a Growing Places Fund amongst many new initiatives.
attachment_1_title: Supporting Local Growth

ignoreDCLG page title: Updating the evidence base on English cities - final report
title: Updating the evidence base on English cities
body:
This report provides an update to the 2006 'State of the English Cities' report, which provided a comprehensive analysis of city performance.

Four years after its publication, and with major changes in the economic and political context, this report seeks to take stock of new evidence and developments on the most critical urban issues. It reviews how the quantitative and qualitative evidence has developed since the publication of the State of the English Cities report, updates the key indicators relating to city performance, and identifies gaps in the evidence base in order to support future policy making.
attachment_1_title: Updating the evidence base on English cities - final report

title: London aggregates working party: monitoring report 2009
body:
This report for 2009 builds upon the London monitoring surveys for the years 2000-08.

It has been prepared from returns made by the operators of quarries, wharves and rail depots in London in response to the aggregate minerals 2009 survey, together with data on applications from London boroughs. The report also puts the findings in the context of the London Plan and the guidelines for aggregates provision.

The findings and recommendations in this report are those of the consultant authors and do not necessarily represent the views or proposed policies of the Department for Communities and Local Government.

body:
Impact Assessment number 36 accompanies _the Building (Amendment) Regulations 2011_.

The Department for Communities and Local Government proposes to proceed with option 2, to authorise the extension of some existing competent person schemes to self-certify the types of work indicated, so as to further reduce the costs and burdens of complying with the Building Regulations at an average net saving/benefit of around Â£2.4 million per year, and help improve compliance.

ignoreDCLG page title: Progress towards the sustainability of the building stock in England and Wales: Third parliamentary report: Sustainable and Secure Buildings Act 2004
title: Progress towards environmentally sustainable buildings: third Parliamentary report
body:
The Sustainable and Secure Buildings Act (SSBA) places a requirement on the Department for Communities and Local Government (DCLG) to publish biennial reports to Parliament to show how/whether Building Regulations and the Standards Division's policies have led to improvements in environmental sustainability in the built environment.

This report covers progress made in the period between 16 November 2008 and 15 November 2010. The Act specifies the areas that the report must cover and these include:

  *  building regulations made over the period and their expected impact
  *  any planned legislation, and proposals for the setting of targets in relation to sustainable buildings

 The report must also cover changes:

  *  in the energy and carbon efficiency of the building stock
  *  the extent to which buildings have their own facilities for generating energy
  *  and the recycling and reuse of construction materials over the period
  *  and an estimate of the number of dwellings in England and Wales at the end of the reporting period
ignoretype from DCLG: Reports and summaries, Legislation and policy
attachment_1_title: Progress towards the sustainability of the building stock in England and Wales: Third parliamentary report: Sustainable and Secure Buildings Act 2004

ignoreDCLG page title: Handypersons Evaluation: Interim key findings
title: Handypersons evaluation
summary: Independent evaluation of the Department for Communities and Local Government (DCLG)'s handyperson programme
body:
This report sets out interim findings from the first year of an independent evaluation of DCLG's handyperson programme. Undertaken by the University of York, the evaluation will measure the success and value for money of the programme and whether the needs of clients were met. It will also assemble evidence on setting up and operating successful services.

These interim findings provide emerging evidence about the preventative nature of handyperson services in avoiding costs elsewhere. Final findings will be available later in 2011. The findings and recommendations in this report are those of the consultant authors and do not necessarily represent the views or proposed policies of DCLG.
attachment_1_title: Handypersons evaluation: interim key findings

ignoreDCLG page title: Modelling business plans for council landlords: Report on model inputs assumptions and outputs
title: Modelling business plans for council landlords
body:
PricewaterhouseCoopers LLP (PwC) was appointed to provide expert financial and technical support to the Department for Communities and Local Government (DCLG) team leading a project to develop a devolved system for the financing of council housing in England.

The project follows on from the work undertaken in phase one and seeks to provide a straightforward financial model and advice to DCLG on the inputs to the financial model, including the values and assumptions used at a national and local level and how the national average cost uplifts established through phase one of the review might be disaggregated locally.

The findings and recommendations in this report are those of the consultant authors and do not necessarily represent the views or proposed policies of DCLG.
attachment_1_title: Modelling business plans for council landlords: Report on model inputs assumptions and outputs

ignoreDCLG page title: The English Indices of Deprivation 2010: Technical Report
title: English indices of deprivation 2010: technical report
body:
The English Indices of Deprivation 2010 is the third release in a series of statistics produced to measure multiple forms of deprivation at the small spatial scale. It updates the Indices of Deprivation 2007 and 2004, retaining broadly the same methodology, domains and indicators.

This report outlines the conceptualisation underpinning the model of multiple deprivation used and describes the indicators and domains that make up the indices.
attachment_1_title: The English Indices of Deprivation 2010: Technical Report

ignoreDCLG page title: Regional and national tenants' organisations
title: Regional and national tenants' organisations
body:
IRIS Consulting were commissioned by the Department for Communities and Local Government (DCLG) in January 2009 to carry out research into regional and national tenants' organisations in England. The main fieldwork for the research was carried out in the period February to August 2009. In the light of comments received this report was revised in June 2010.

The remit for the study was to identify the regional and national tenants' organisations and to assess their strengths, weaknesses and opportunities. This information and assessment would be used by DCLG and the NTV and Tenant Services Authority (TSA) to make informed decisions about how best to develop and support such organisations in the future.

The findings and recommendations in this report are those of the consultant authors and do not necessarily represent the views or proposed policies of DCLG.
attachment_1_title: Regional and national tenants' organisations

ignoreDCLG page title: Local solutions for adults facing multiple deprivation: Adults facing Chronic Exclusion evaluation â‚¬â€œ final report
title: Local solutions for adults facing multiple deprivation
body:
The adults facing chronic exclusion (ACE) programme tests new ways of working with excluded people who do not access services in the community because their lives are chaotic and their needs are too complex. All the interventions offer support from a consistent, trusted adult.

The pilots began in 2007, and were a cross Whitehall initiative sponsored by the Cabinet Office, led by Department for Communities and Local Government and funded by Department for Health, Department for Works and Pensions and the Home Office. Twelve different projects have been working across England.
attachment_1_title: Simple but effective: Local solutions for adults facing multiple deprivation: Adults facing Chronic Exclusion evaluation - final report
attachment_2_title: Adults facing Chronic Exclusion Programme: Evaluation findings - Summary

ignoreDCLG page title: Disabled Facilities Grant allocation methodology and means test: Final report
title: Disabled Facilities Grant allocation methodology and means test
summary: An evaluation by the Building Research Establishment (BRE) of the allocation of the Disabled Facilities Grant
body:
The Department for Communities and Local Government commissioned the BRE to evaluate the current method for allocating the Disabled Facilities Grant to local authorities. This was with a view to proposing new methods that were simpler, fairer and more transparent.

The BRE approach takes into account:

* people claiming disability-related benefits
* the proportion of the population aged over 60
* the proportion of local authority-owned housing stock
* regional variations in building costs

It explores access to housing advice, refuge provision, other specialist accommodation, access to settled accommodation and the role of floating support.

The findings and recommendations in this report are those of the consultant authors and do not necessarily represent the views or proposed policies of the Department for Communities and Local Government.

ignoreDCLG page title: The Working Group on Condition Information in the Home Buying & Selling Process: Final Report
title: Condition information in the home buying and selling process
body:
The previous government established the working group on condition information in the home buying and selling process to look at the issues around:

  * consumer demand for property condition information
  * how best to deliver such information to consumers
  * how to involve Home Inspectors
  * the role of the property industry in taking this forward

To assist in developing an evidence base for the working group, Ipsos MORI was commissioned to conduct a short research exercise looking at the role of property condition information in the home buying and selling process. Their 3 reports along with the final report of the working group are available to download.
attachment_1_title: The Working Group on Condition Information in the Home Buying & Selling Process: Final Report
attachment_2_title: The role of condition information in the home buying and selling process: Key findings from research conducted by Ipsos MORI and DTZ

attachment_4_title:
The role of condition information in the home buying and selling process
Findings from an online survey and qualitative research among home buyers and sellers

ignoreDCLG page title: New Forecast Scenarios for UK Mortgage Arrears and Possessions
title: Mortgage arrears and possessions: forecasts
body:
In January 2012 DCLG commissioned Professor Muellbauer, of Oxford University, to update his model which forecasts repossessions and loans in arrears in the UK and to produce updated forecasts.

This research report sets out the changes to the model since the last report and the revised forecasts. This update led to the inclusion of an extra eight observations, together with a number of data revisions. The update also means that the forecast of loans in arrears and repossession now draws upon a range of economic forecast scenarios based mainly on underlying forecast data from the Office for Budget Responsibility but also from Oxford Economics for comparison.

The new forecasts represent an improved outlook for both repossessions and arrears compared to the previous forecast. The main reason being the change in interest rate expectations; interest rates are now expected to rise much later; in mid 2013, instead of early 2012.
attachment_1_title: New Forecast Scenarios for UK Mortgage Arrears and Possessions

body:

These areas will help local planning authorities better address housing needs across market areas, including identifying areas where they could benefit from partnership working in housing markets that cross administrative boundaries.

Further details, lookup files and maps can be accessed from [http://www.ncl.ac.uk/curds/research/NHPAU.htm](http://www.ncl.ac.uk/curds/research/NHPAU.htm).

The findings and recommendations in this report are those of the consultant authors and do not necessarily represent the views or proposed policies of the Department for Communities and Local Government.

ignoreDCLG page title: Housing and Regional Economic Disparities - Economics paper 5
title: Housing and regional economic disparities: economics paper 5
body:
This paper is the fifth in the DCLG economics papers series. Regional economic disparities are a long-standing feature of the UK economy, and regional house price differences or planning policy are often cited as contributing factors.

Housing is likely to contribute to regional disparities, but there is a danger of blaming housing for more deep-seated social issues.

Although policy undoubtedly is important, this paper points to the more subtle influences of housing markets in economic outcomes. In particular, the role of housing in influencing human and physical capital stocks is examined. While more research is required, this report argues that history matters and that there are no quick fixes.
attachment_1_title: Housing and Regional Economic Disparities - Economics paper 5

ignoreDCLG page title: Housing Wealth Inequality - Economics paper 6: Volume 1
title: Housing wealth inequality: economics paper 6
body:
These papers are the sixth in the DCLG economics papers series. Housing has become a large part of our lives and more people rely on housing investment to form their wealth assets.

Volume I of this paper sets out the results of a seminar held in DCLG which looked at understanding the different forms of wealth inequality and its effects on social mobility and chances.

Volume II consists of an article by Gwilym Price and Eric Levin from the University of Glasgow, which examines changes to housing wealth inequality.
attachment_1_title: Housing Wealth Inequality - Economics paper 6: Volume 1
attachment_2_title: Measuring Changes in Housing Wealth Inequality - Economics paper 6: Volume 2

ignoreDCLG page title: The impacts of restricting housing supply on house prices and affordability: Final report
title: Impact of restricting housing supply on house prices
body:
The research explores the underlying causes of the English housing affordability crisis. The report finds causal evidence that regulatory constraints have had a serious negative long-run impact on housing affordability and have increase house price volatility.

The report goes on to propose an alternative solution of giving greater incentives to local planning authorities to encourage housing development.
attachment_1_title: The impacts of restricting housing supply on house prices and affordability: Final report
attachment_2_title: The impacts of restricting housing supply on house prices and affordability: Executive summary

ignoreDCLG page title: Promoting investment in private rented housing supply: International policy comparisons
title: Promoting investment in private rented housing: international policy comparisons
body:
This study investigated the range of policy frameworks currently in place in high income countries to promote investment in private rented housing supply. The research began with a statistical overview of the private rented sector in the 27 high-income OECD member countries.

The demand for and the supply of private rented housing in these countries was compared with England, although the policy-related conclusions from this study apply more broadly to the UK.

Further detailed information about the outputs from this work can be found at - [http://www.dmu.ac.uk/faculties/business_and_law/business/housing/research/PRS.jsp](http://www.dmu.ac.uk/faculties/business_and_law/business/housing/research/PRS.jsp).
attachment_1_title: Promoting investment in private rented housing supply: International policy comparisons

ignoreDCLG page title: Effectiveness of schemes to enable households at risk of domestic violence to remain in their own homes
title: Effectiveness of schemes to enable people at risk of domestic violence to remain in their own homes
body:
A Sanctuary Scheme is a multi-agency victim centred initiative which aims to enable households at risk of violence to remain safely in their own homes by installing a 'Sanctuary' in the home and through the provision of support to the household.

This evaluation was carried out in 2009/10 and involved interviews with national stakeholders, local case studies (interviews with service providers, support providers, local stakeholders, and service users), and a cost-benefit analysis. It shows that overall Sanctuary Schemes were thought to have been successful in their main aim of providing a safe alternative for households at risk of domestic violence, and preventing the disruption associated with homelessness.

It also highlights that there are different types of installation and security measures and also variation in the way schemes operate post installation. Nevertheless, respondents in all areas reported similar outcomes and, for the most part, service users reported positive experiences. A summary of this research report and also a practice guide have also been published.
attachment_1_title: Effectiveness of schemes to enable households at risk of domestic violence to remain in their own homes

ignoreDCLG page title: 245: Effectiveness of schemes to enable households at risk of domestic violence to remain in their own homes
title: Housing research summary 245: effectiveness of schemes to enable households at risk of domestic violence to remain in their own homes
body:
A Sanctuary Scheme is a multi-agency victim centred initiative which aims to enable households at risk of violence to remain safely in their own homes by installing a 'Sanctuary' in the home and through the provision of support to the household. In 2009/10 a research team led by Anwen Jones from the Centre for Housing Policy, University of York carried out an evaluation of  Sanctuary Schemes.

This summary provides an overview of key findings and good practice points. A full research report and also a separate practice guide have also been published.

title: Aggregate minerals survey for England and Wales: 2009 results
body:
The aggregate minerals survey provides in-depth and up to date information on national and regional sales, inter-regional flows, consumption and permitted reserves of aggregates. The report is the collation of the data for primary aggregates in England and Wales from the survey undertaken for 2009.

This second edition replaces the version published on 23 May 2011. The updated report also presents data on the movement and consumption of primary aggregates, by local planning authority.

The findings and recommendations in this report are those of the consultant authors and do not necessarily represent the views or proposed policies of the Department for Communities and Local Government.

ignoreDCLG page title: Cost of building to the Code for sustainable homes - updated cost review
title: Cost of building housing to the code for sustainable homes standard: updated cost review
body: The Code for sustainable homes is the national standard for assessing the sustainability of new housing in England, Wales and Northern Ireland. This document aims to provide guidance as to the costs of building housing to Code standards. It updates the two previous Code cost reports and is based on a much larger availability of market-tested industry data.
attachment_1_title: Cost of building to the Code for sustainable homes - updated cost review

ignoreDCLG page title: The impact of European fire test and classification standards on wallpaper and similar decorative linings
title: The impact of European fire test and classification standards on wallpaper and similar decorative linings
body:
The overall aim of this project was to understand the impact of European fire test and classification standards on building regulations and UK industry, in particular, on wallpapers and similar decorative linings.

The outcome from the project would seek to establish the realistic performance of these types of products and determine whether the classifications that they achieved were appropriate to the actual hazard to life that they posed.

This report details the test methodology, results and observations from the fire tests undertaken.

The findings and recommendations in this report are those of the consultant authors and do not necessarily represent the views or proposed policies of the Department for Communities and Local Government.
attachment_1_title: The impact of European fire test and classification standards on wallpaper and similar decorative linings

ignoreDCLG page title: Investigation into overheating in homes: Analysis of gaps and recommendations
title: Investigation into overheating in homes
body:
This report identifies the main gaps in the literature on overheating in homes, and recommends areas where further work might be of most value.

The analysis has been carried out on behalf of Government by a consortium led by AECOM, and supported by the London School of Hygiene and Tropical Medicine and University College London.

It is the second project output; the first being a [Literature Review](http://www.communities.gov.uk/publications/planningandbuilding/overheatingliterature) covering whether overheating is occurring in new dwellings, in existing dwellings and whether or not retrofitting/refurbishing existing dwellings is likely to increase the risk of overheating.

The findings and recommendations in this report are those of the consultant authors and do not necessarily represent the views or proposed policies of the Department for Communities and Local Government.
attachment_1_title: Investigation into overheating in homes: Analysis of gaps and recommendations

ignoreDCLG page title: Planning Costs and Fees: Final Report
title: Planning costs and fees: final report
body:
This research report provides data on the costs of fee-chargeable development management and looks specifically at whether planning application fees cover local authority costs.

The research also seeks to identify methods that would enable local authorities to calculate costs as a basis for locally-set planning application fees.

The findings and recommendations in this report are those of the consultant authors and do not necessarily represent the views or proposed policies of the Department for Communities and Local Government.
attachment_1_title: Planning Costs and Fees: Final Report

ignoreDCLG page title: Valuing the Benefits of Regeneration
title: Valuing the benefits of regeneration
body: The Department commissioned this study to examine how the benefits of regeneration might be valued. It is designed to provide an analytical framework that will underpin a programme of research on the value of the benefits from regeneration and how they compare with the relevant costs. The intention is to establish a robust evidence base, identify potential challenges and provide constructive suggestions on how these could be overcome.

ignoreDCLG page title: Household Projections, 2008 to 2033, England
title: Household projections (2008 to 2033) in England
body:
The latest national statistics on household projections to 2033 for England were released in line with the Code of Practice for Official Statistics on 26th November 2010.

This Statistical Release presents National Statistics on the projected number of households in England and its regions to 2033. The figures in this release are based on the 2008-based population projections and replace the 2006-based household projections released in March 2009.

The household projections are produced by applying projected household formation rates to the population projections published by the Office for National Statistics. The assumptions underlying national household and population projections are demographic trend based.

They do not attempt to predict the impact that future government policies, changing economic circumstances or other factors might have on demographic behaviour. They provide the household levels and structures that would result if the assumptions based on previous demographic trends in the population and household formation rates were to be realised in practice.

Key points from the latest release are:

  * The number of households in England is projected to grow to 27.5 million in 2033, an increase of 5.8 million (27 per cent) over 2008, or 232,000 households per year.
  * Population growth is the main driver of household growth, accounting for nearly three-quarters of the increase in households between 2008 and 2033.
  * One person households are projected to increase by 159,000 per year, equating to two-thirds of the increase in households.
  * By 2033, 19 per cent of the household population of England is projected to live alone, compared with 14 per cent in 2008.
  * By 2033, 33 per cent of households will be headed by those aged 65 or over, up from 26 per cent in 2008.
  * The South East region has the largest absolute increase in households of 39,500 per year from 2008 to 2033, amounting to a 28 per cent increase on the number in 2008.
  * The North East region shows the smallest growth in households, at 8,500 per year from 2008 to 2033, amounting to a 19 per cent increase on the number in 2008.
  * The 2008-based projections show a lower growth in households compared with the 2006-based projections, equating to 20,500 fewer households per year between 2008 and 2031 in England.

ignoreDCLG page title: Affordable Housing Supply, England, 2009 to 2010
title: Affordable housing supply in England: 2009 to 2010
body:
The latest statistics on gross affordable housing supply in England were released on Thursday 28 October 2010.

The key points were:

  * A total of 57,730 gross additional affordable homes were supplied in England in 2009-10. This is an increase of 4 per cent on the 55,570 (revised) affordable homes supplied in 2008-09 and the highest number since 1995-96.
  * 33,120 new affordable homes were provided for social rent in 2009-10, an increase of 7 per cent on 2008-09. 24,610 homes were provided through intermediate housing schemes, including shared ownership and shared equity, nearly unchanged on 2008-09.
  * There were 46,980 new build affordable homes in 2009-10 which is 81 per cent of the total supply of new affordable homes compared to 77 per cent last year.
  * 51,140 homes were delivered with grant from the Homes and Communities Agency in 2009-10 (89 per cent of total supply). Around 82 per cent of these were new build homes, an increase on last year (78 per cent).
  * Collectively, more than half of all new affordable homes were supplied in London (24 per cent), the South East (19 per cent) and the South West (11 per cent) in 2009-10.
  * There was an increase in affordable housing supply in six of the nine regions in England. The North East saw the largest annual growth both in absolute (730) and percentage terms (52 per cent).
attachment_1_title: Affordable Housing Supply, England, 2009-10
attachment_2_title: Affordable Housing Supply, England, 2009-10
attachment_3_title: Pre-release Access list: Affordable Housing

ignoreDCLG page title: Affordable Housing Supply, England, 2010 to 2011
title: Affordable housing supply in England: 2010 to 2011
body:
The latest statistics on gross affordable housing supply in England were released on Wednesday 5 October 2011.

The key points were:

  * A total of 60,630 gross additional affordable homes were supplied in England in 2010-11. This is an increase of 5 per cent on the 58,010 (revised) affordable homes supplied in 2009-10 and the highest number since 1995-96.
  * 39,170 new affordable homes were provided for social rent in 2010-11, an increase of 18 per cent on 2009-10. 21,460 homes were provided through intermediate housing schemes, including shared ownership and shared equity, down by 13 per cent on 2009-10.
  * There were 53,380 new build affordable homes in 2010-11 which is 88 per cent of the total supply of additional affordable homes compared to 81 per cent last year and is the highest percentage recorded.
  * 55,250 homes were delivered with grant from the Homes and Communities Agency in 2010-11 (91 per cent of total supply). Around 88 per cent of these were new build homes.
  * Collectively, half of all additional affordable homes were supplied in London (23 per cent), the South East (15 per cent) and the South West (12 per cent) in 2010-11.
  * There was an increase in affordable housing supply in seven of the nine regions in England. Yorkshire and the Humber saw the largest annual growth both in absolute (1,450) and percentage terms (50 per cent). Decreases were observed in the South East (-17 per cent) and East (-14 per cent).
attachment_1_title: Affordable Housing Supply, England, 2010 to 2011
attachment_2_title: Affordable Housing Supply, England, 2010 to 2011
attachment_3_title: Pre-release Access list: Affordable Housing

ignoreDCLG page title: Local authority capital expenditure and receipts - England: 2009-10 final outturn (revised)
title: Local authority capital expenditure and receipts in England: 2009 to 2010 final outturn (revised)
body:
The latest national statistics on final outturn local authority capital expenditure and receipts in the financial year April 2009 to March 2010 were originally released on 28 October 2010 under arrangements approved by the UK Statistics Authority. A revised version has been released today under arrangements approved by the UK Statistics Authority, incorporating amendments made by four local authorities. The total capital expenditure has increased by 0.07 per cent. Capital receipts remain the same.

The key points from the latest release are:

  * The underlying trend in capital expenditure shows an increase of 8 per cent from 2008-09 to 2009-10, to Â£21.4 billion.
  * Capital expenditure has risen by 28 per cent in the last four years, nearly 16 per cent in real terms.
  * Capital receipts remain well below the 2007-08 level, at Â£1.4 billion. This reflects a drop in the sale of assets by local authorities. The in-year capital receipts of Â£1.4 billion were more than offset by the use of Â£1.6 billion of capital receipts to finance expenditure.
  * The Greater London Authority (GLA) accounts for Â£3.2 billion (nearly 15 per cent) of total capital expenditure in 2009-10. Â£2.7 billion of this is the expenditure of Transport for London.

body:
The latest national statistics on the provisional outturn figures of local authority capital expenditure and receipts in the financial year April 2009 to March 2010 and forecast figures for April 2010 to March 2011 was released on 29 June 2010 under arrangements approved by the UK Statistics Authority.

The latest statistics release includes data from 2005-06 to 2010-11 and updates those statistics previously released on 18 June 2009 and 1 July 2009.

  * Capital expenditure by local authorities in England rose to Â£21.7 billion in 2009-10, a year-on-year increase of 10 per cent and is forecast to rise to Â£24.4 billion in 2010-11, a year-on-year increase of 13 per cent
  * Capital receipts fell again in 2009-10 to Â£1.2 billion but are forecast to rise back to Â£1.4 billion in 2010-11
  * The largest percentage increase in capital expenditure in 2009-10 is in transport (27 per cent). This increase primarily relates to the Greater London Authority's contribution to the Crossrail project. Education accounts for 26 per cent of capital expenditure

The latest statistical release includes data from 2006-07 to 2010-11 and incorporates minor changes to the aggregate figures and provides additional annexes which were not in the second provisional outturn published on 8 September 2011.

  * Capital expenditure by local authorities in England rose to Â£23.1 billion in 2010-11, a year-on-year increase of 8 per cent, due mainly to the Greater London Authority's (GLA) expenditure via Transport for London (TfL). If the GLA's expenditure were excluded from the England totals, then capital expenditure was unchanged from 2009-10
  * Capital expenditure has risen by nearly 42 per cent in the last four years, nearly 28 per cent in real terms
  * Capital receipts were unchanged in 2010-11, at Â£1.5 billion, from 2009-10.

title: Local authority capital expenditure and receipts in England: 2011 to 2012 provisional outturn and 2012 to 2013 forecast
body:
The latest national statistics on the provisional outturn figures of local authority capital expenditure and receipts in the financial year April 2011 to March 2012 and forecast figures for April 2012 to March 2013 were released on 28 June 2012 under arrangements approved by the UK Statistics Authority.

The latest statistical release includes data from 2007-08 to 2012-13.

  * Capital expenditure by local authorities in England excluding special factors of Housing Revenue Account reform fell to Â£20.7 billion in 2011-12, a year-on-year decrease of more than 10 per cent, due partly to a reduction in expenditure on new construction and conversion. It is forecast to rise to Â£21.4 billion in 2012-13, a year-on-year rise of 3 per cent
  * Capital receipts have increased significantly in 2011-12 to Â£1.8 billion excluding special factors of Housing Revenue Account reform, a year-on-year increase of 22 per cent. Receipts are forecast to rise to Â£2.0 billion in 2012-13
  * The percentage decrease in capital expenditure in 2011-12 is nearly 14 per cent in housing, almost 13 per cent in highways and transport, and 9 per cent in education

**Special factors**

There has been a reform to the Housing Revenue Account system of payments which is reflected in the financial statistics shown in this statistical release.

ignoreDCLG page title: Local authority capital expenditure and receipts, England: 2011-12 forecast revision
title: Local authority capital expenditure and receipts in England: 2011 to 2012 forecast revision
body:
The 2011-12 forecast previously published on 28 June 2011 as part of 2010-11 provisional outturn and 2011-12 forecast has been revised due to amendments made to the forecast expenditure figures for 2011-12 in Tables 1, 2, 5a and b, 6, 7, 9 and Annexes A(1), (2) and (3). The numbering of the tables has been changed.

The main change to the national level figures was due to revised Greater London Authority (GLA) data. To produce accurate national figures internal transactions between bodies within the GLA group (see definition in the terminology section of the Statistical Release) have been removed to give a true picture of expenditure and financing.

The two main figures that are impacted are capital grants (a removal of Â£868 million) and General Fund CERA (see definition in the terminology section of the statistical release) (a net removal of Â£446 million). These transactions were associated with Crossrail financing and expenditure and this has impacted on the headline comparison in capital expenditure made in the original release. It was also decided to input the other three revised returns, with minor amendments, that had been received after the publication of the statistical release.

title: Gypsy and traveller caravan count: January 2011
body:
This release presents data from the count of Gypsy and traveller caravans in England which took place on 27 January 2011. The bi-annual count takes place in January and July, recording the number of caravans on both authorised and unauthorised sites across England.

In addition, the January 2011 count also included a count of the caravans/moveable dwellings occupied by travelling showpeople in each local authority in England. This information has been published as Experimental Statistics. This is a first attempt to capture this information which achieved partial coverage across England. Further information on experimental statistics can be found on the Office for National Statistics website (See link right).

ignoreDCLG page title: Code for sustainable homes and Energy Performance of Buildings: Cumulative and quarterly data up to December 2010
title: Code for sustainable homes and energy performance of buildings data: December 2010
body:
The latest official statistics on the Code for sustainable homes and Average Energy Efficiency (SAP ratings) were released on 22 February 2011.

Statistics in this release relating to the Code for sustainable homes show the number of dwellings that have been certified to the standards set out in the Code Technical Guide.

Key points from the latest release are:

  * There were 18,339 post construction stage certificates and 46,519 design stage certificates issued up to and including December 2010.
  * 11 per cent of homes with post construction certificates and 21 per cent of those with design stage certificates have been built for the private sector. 89 per cent of homes with post construction certificates and 79 per cent of those with design stage certificates have been built for the public sector.
  * Between April 2007 and December 2010, 40,017 dwellings at the design stage received a three star rating and 289 dwellings received a six star rating.
  * Between April 2007 and December 2010, 16,513 dwellings at post-construction stage received a three star rating and 30 dwellings received a six star rating.
  * The majority of the certificates issued since April 2007 at design stage (86 per cent) and at post construction stage (90 per cent) have been awarded at Code level 3.
  * The average energy efficiency, SAP rating of new homes in England was 81.7 and in Wales 80.6 for the quarter October - December 2010. This is an increase on the same quarter 2009 from 80.2 in England and 79.3 in Wales.

### Revision

A number of errors were contained within these published statistics.

These errors related to the number of Code Certificates (at both Design and Post-Construction stage) issued by 22 of the 25 Welsh Planning Authorities. Although these errors affected the number of cases for individual Planning Authorities, it did not affect the overall total of cases in Wales. The statistics for England and Northern Ireland remain unchanged. The Cumulative and Quarterly Data commentary (.PDF and Word documents) are therefore unchanged as these relate to national statistics which remain the same.

We apologise for the error which was caused by an anomaly in the transfer of data which has now been rectified. The document 'Table of Welsh statistics changes' below sets out the data as originally published and as amended.

The published quarterly statistics have now been amended with the changes being denoted by an 'R' in the appropriate column. These were published 26 August 2011.

ignoreDCLG page title: Collection rates for council tax and non-domestic rates in England 2010-11
title: Collection rates for Council Tax and non-domestic rates in England 2010 to 2011
body:
Details of the collection rates for Council Tax and national non-domestic rates in England in 2010-11 were announced on 29 June 2011.

The latest statistics release includes data from 2006-07 to 2010-11 and updates those statistics previously released on 22 June 2010.

  * Local authorities in England collected Â£21.9 billion in Council Taxes by the end of March 2011 out of a total of Â£22.5 billion collectable. This gave a national average in-year collection rate for council tax in England of 97.3 per cent in 2010-11, an increase of 0.2 percentage points over 2009-10.
  * Local authorities in England collected Â£19.6 billion in non-domestic rates by the end of March 2011 out of a total of Â£20.0 billion collectable. This gave a national average in-year collection rate for non-domestic rates in England of 98.0 per cent in 2010-11, an increase of 0.2 percentage points over 2009-10.
  * Over the last four years, the national collection rate for council tax has increased by 0.4 of a percentage point. In the same period the national collection rate for national non-domestic rates in 2010-11 has fallen by 0.7 of a percentage point.
  * The average collection rate of non-domestic rates fell in all regions in the period 2006-07 to 2010-11; the largest fall, 1.0 percentage points, occurred in the North West.

  * Local authorities in England collected Â£22.1 billion in council taxes by the end of March 2012 out of a total of Â£22.7 billion collectable. This gave a national average in-year collection rate for council tax in England of 97.3 per cent in 2011-12, no change over 2010-11.
  * Local authorities in England collected Â£20.8 billion in non-domestic rates by the end of March 2012 out of a total of Â£21.3 billion collectable. This gave a national average in-year collection rate for non-domestic rates in England of 97.8 per cent in 2011-12, a decrease of 0.2 percentage points over 2010-11.
  * Over the last four years, the national collection rate for council tax has increased by 0.2 of a percentage point. In the same period the national collection rate for national non-domestic rates has fallen by 1.0 percentage points.
  * The average collection rate of non-domestic rates fell in all regions in the period 2007-08 to 2011-12; the largest fall, 1.9 percentage points, occurred in the North West.

ignoreDCLG page title: Council tax levels set by local authorities in England - 2011-12
title: Council Tax levels set by local authorities in England: 2011 to 2012
body:
Details of the level of council tax set by local authorities in England for 2011-12 were announced on 23 March 2011. This latest statistical release also contains data from 2002-03 to 2011-12.

The key points from the latest release are:

  * The average Band D council tax set by local authorities in England for 2011-12 will be Â£1,439, (2010-11 Â£1,439).
  * In England in 2011-12, the average council tax per dwelling will be Â£1,196 compared with Â£1,195 in 2010-11, an increase of 0.1 per cent.
  * Excluding parishes, no local authority has increased its Band D council tax.
  * The average Band D council tax will be Â£1,308 in London, Â£1,399 in metropolitan areas and Â£1,484 in shire areas.
  * Parish precepts in 2011-12 will total Â£367 million. This represents an increase of 2.8 per cent over the 2010-11 figure of Â£357 million. The average Band D parish precept in 2011-12 will be Â£45.88, an increase of 2.1 per cent.
  * The total tax base used for setting council taxes for 2011-12 was 18.4 million Band D equivalent dwellings. This represents an increase of 0.7 per cent over the figure of 18.2 million for 2010-11.

title: Council Tax levels set by local authorities in England: 2012 to 2013
body:
Details of the level of council tax set by local authorities in England for 2012-13 were announced on 21 March 2012.

These statistics were superseded by Council tax levels set by local authorities in England - 2012-13 (revised) published on 9 May 2012, which provides details of the level of council tax set by local authorities in England for 2012-13. The release incorporates minor revisions to the information published on 21 March 2012, and can be found under 'Related publications' below.

The key points from the latest release are:

  * The average Band D council tax set by local authorities in England for 2012-13 will be Â£1,444, (2011-12 Â£1,439) an increase of 0.3 per cent.
  * In England in 2012-13, the average council tax per dwelling will be Â£1,201 compared with Â£1,196 in 2011-12, an increase of 0.4 per cent.
  * The average Band D council tax will be Â£1,304 in London, Â£1,401 in metropolitan areas and Â£1,492 in shire areas.
  * In 2012-13, 85 per cent of all authorities will benefit from the Council tax freeze grant.
  * Parish precepts in 2012-13 will total Â£384 million. This represents an increase of 4.6 per cent over the 2011-12 figure of Â£367 million. The average Band D parish precept in 2012-13 will be Â£47.80, an increase of 4.2 per cent.
  * The total tax base used for setting council taxes for 2012-13 was 18.5 million Band D equivalent dwellings. This represents an increase of 0.7 per cent over the figure of 18.4 million for 2011-12.
