ignoreDCLG page title: General Approval to the Delegation of Housing Management
title: General approval to the delegation of housing management
body:
Section 27 of the Housing Act 1985 (as amended) sets out the power for local authorities to delegate their housing management functions, subject to the approval of the Secretary of State. Section 27 permits the Secretary of State to issue consent either specifically or generally.

The letter sent to chief executives of Local Authorities in England is available to download below.
attachment_1_title: General Approval to the Delegation of Housing Management

ignoreDCLG page title: Guidance Note on Empty Dwelling Management Orders
title: Empty Dwelling Management Orders: guidance
body:
This guidance note is intended to assist local housing authorities in understanding the powers contained in the Housing Act 2004relating to Empty Dwelling Management Orders. It is not intended to be an authoritative interpretation of the legislation and readers must not rely on it as an authoritative source. Where there are any doubts about the interpretation of the legislation readers are strongly advised to seek their own independent legal advice.

This guidance note is intended to apply to England.
attachment_1_title: Guidance Note on Empty Dwelling Management Orders

ignoreDCLG page title: Guidance following the fire case at Camberwell London
title: Camberwell, London fire: guidance
body:
This letter from Housing Minister John Healey to Local Housing Authorities in England sets out how the government will evaluate the fire that took place in Camberwell, London, on 3 July 2009. It also asks authorities to provide reassurance to their tenants by reminding them how to protect themselves from fire.

The Tenant Services Authority (TSA) has also written to Registered Social Landlords providing advice to them on practical measures they should take in the light of the fire
attachment_1_title: Guidance following the fire case at Camberwell London

ignoreDCLG page title: Guidance for Local Authorities and Housing Management Organisations : Contracting out of Anti-social Behaviour Order functions
title: Contracting out of anti-social behaviour order functions
body:
This guidance is statutory, but tries to avoid being prescriptive. It provides local authorities and HMOs with a framework to follow whilst allowing flexibility based on local circumstances.

It also outlines those areas which the Government expects local authorities and HMOs to have properly considered when deciding to contract out ASBO functions.

The guidance does not duplicate nor override guidance issued by the Home Office on the use of ASBOs. Rather it focuses on the contractual relationship between local authorities in their strategic role and housing managers as frontline 'deliverers'.
attachment_1_title: Guidance for Local Authorities and Housing Management Organisations: Contracting out of Anti-social Behaviour Order functions

ignoreDCLG page title: Guidance on Arms Length Management of Local Authority Housing - 2004 Edition
title: Guidance on arms length management of local authority housing: 2004 edition
body: This guidance is about the arms length management organisation (ALMO) option for local authorities that wish to improve their housing management services and seeking additional resources to invest in bringing their housing stock up to the decent homes standard. It replaces the guidance on this subject issued by the ODPM in March 2003. It covers the key policy and operational features of ALMOs, and sets out the criteria for bids for additional resources in Rounds 5 and 6 of the programme, which are for additional expenditure expected to start in 2006/07 and 2007/08 respectively.
attachment_1_title: Guidance on Arms Length Management of Local Authority Housing - 2004 Edition

ignoreDCLG page title: Guidance on Managing Unauthorised Camping
title: Managing unauthorised camping
body:
This guidance, produced jointly by the ODPM and the Home Office, provides best practice advice on managing cases of unauthorised camping.

Supplementary guidance on the new provisions in the Anti-social Behaviour Act 2003 was produced in March 2005.
attachment_1_title: Guidance on Managing Unauthorised Camping

ignoreDCLG page title: Guidance on managing anti-social behaviour related to Gypsies and Travellers
title: Managing anti-social behaviour related to gypsies and travellers
body: This guidance has been produced to support local authorities, the police and other agencies and to encourage consistency amongst agencies in their approach to tackling anti-social behaviour associated with gypsies and travellers - whether they are the victims or the perpetrators - and sets out the powers and tools available and how they may be used.
attachment_1_title: Guidance on managing anti-social behaviour related to Gypsies and Travellers

ignoreDCLG page title: Guidance on stock valuation for resource accounting
title: Guidance on stock valuation for resource accounting
body: This guidance updates the guidance published in 2000 to local authorities on the bases and methods of valuation for housing revenue account assets for resource accounting. The guidance is appropriate for all housing revenue account valuations from April 2005 and until further guidance is issued, if appropriate.
attachment_1_title: Guidance on Stock valuation for Resource Accounting - Updated and Revised July 2005

ignoreDCLG page title: Guidance on the use of Family Intervention Tenancies
title: Family intervention tenancies
body:
This guidance is aimed at social landlords and their use of family intervention tenancies. These tenancies were introduced in the Housing and Regeneration Act 2008 and became available for use on 1 January 2009.

This guidance outlines what considerations social landlords, family intervention projects and other agencies involved in delivering support to households who have been involved in anti-social behaviour should make when considering the use of family intervention tenancies.
attachment_1_title: Guidance on the use of Family Intervention Tenancies

ignoreDCLG page title: Guide on Effective Rent Arrears Management
title: Effective rent arrears management
body: This guide supports the summary and the Improving the Effectiveness of Rent Arrears Management: Good Practice Guidance published by ODPM (now the Department for Communities and Local Government) in June 2005. It draws on the findings of research carried out by Glasgow and Heriot Watt Universities on the use of possession actions and evictions by social landlords.
attachment_1_title: Guide on Effective Rent Arrears Management

ignoreDCLG page title: Guide to Effective Use of Enforcement Powers - Part 2: Unauthorised Development of Caravan Sites
title: Unauthorised development of caravan sites: using enforcement powers
body:
This guidance is intended to inform planning enforcement officers, elected members of local planning authorities, and interested members of the public how the planning enforcement system can be used to prevent the stationing of caravans on land in contravention of planning control.

It does not seek to set out the detailed steps required in taking enforcement action, but instead to provide an overview of how the system can work, and tips on good practice. Detailed information on how planning enforcement powers should be used is contained in separate legislation and guidance. Information on where this can be found is at the end of the guidance.
attachment_1_title: Guide to Effective Use of Enforcement Powers - Part 2: Unauthorised Development of Caravan Sites

ignoreDCLG page title: Guide to Social Rent Reforms
title: Social rent reforms
body: In December 2000 the department published a policy statement, Quality and Choice: A Decent Home for All - The Way Forward for Housing, which proposed that rent setting in the social housing sector should be brought onto a common system based upon relative property values and local earnings levels. This guide sets out the details underpinning the policy statement and provides background information on the implications of the proposals for tenants and landlords.
attachment_1_title: Guide to social rent reforms

ignoreDCLG page title: Guide to effective use of enforcement powers - Part 1: Unauthorised encampments
title: Unauthorised encampments: using enforcement powers
body:
This document is intended for elected officals and others in the community who have an interest in how unauthorised camping by gypsies and travellers is managed in their area. It provides information  to local authority officers and landlowners on options for dealing with incidents of unauthorised camping.

This guidance was produced to meet the government's objective to ensure that the settled community and gypsies and travellers live together peacefully.
attachment_1_title: Guide to effective use of enforcement powers - Part 1: Unauthorised encampments

ignoreDCLG page title: Gypsy and Traveller Accommodation Needs Assessments: Guidance
title: Gypsy and traveller accommodation needs assessments
body: This guidance aims to provide advice on carrying out an assessment of the accommodation needs of gypsies and travellers. It is not exhaustive or prescriptive. While it is recommended that the basic principles outlined here should be followed, the exact approach will need to be adapted to local circumstances.
attachment_1_title: Gypsy and Traveller Accommodation Needs Assessments: Guidance

ignoreDCLG page title: Gypsy and Traveller Site Management Good Practice Guide
title: Gypsy and traveller site management
body:
This document provides good practice guidance on all facets of managing gypsy and traveller sites. It is intended to help new and existing managers maintain well-run and sustainable sites which provide a safe environment for residents and their families.

It will help to clarify the respective roles and responsibilities of management and residents alike, deals with permanent and transit site accommodation and offers advice on everyday issues.

It will also help to ensure sites work well and fulfil their part in promoting good relations with the wider community in the area.
attachment_1_title: Gypsy and Traveller Site Management Good Practice Guide

ignoreDCLG page title: HHSRS Operating Guidance  - Housing Act 2004: Guidance about inspections and assessment of hazards given under Section 9
title: Inspections and assessment of hazards: Housing Health and Safety Rating System operating guidance
body:
The Housing Health and Safety Rating System (HHSRS) is a risk based evaluation tool to help local authorities identify and protect against potential risks and hazards to health and safety from any deficiencies identified in dwellings. It was introduced under the Housing Act 2004 and came into effect on 6 April 2006. It applies to residential properties in England.

The HHSRS assesses 29 categories of housing hazard, each hazard has a weighting which will help determine whether the property is rated as having Category 1 (serious) or Category 2 (other).
attachment_1_title: HHSRS Operating Guidance - Housing Act 2004: Guidance about inspections and assessment of hazards given under Section 9

ignoreDCLG page title: HHSRS: Cold homes in the private rented sector  the role of local authorities
title: Cold homes in the private rented sector: the role of local authorities
body:
The Department for Communities and Local Government wrote to chief executives of local authorities highlighting the need for councils to act strategically by using powers to tackle cold homes in the private rented sector. It refers to:

* the government announcement on increased funding for national energy efficiency schemes to help households to reduce their fuel bills
* the need for councils to use their enforcement powers for the hazard, "excess cold" under Part 1 of the Housing Act 2004(HHSRS)
* funding streams available to assist councils through the Regional Housing Pot
attachment_1_title: HHSRS: Cold homes in the private rented sector - the role of Local Authorities

ignoreDCLG page title: Homelessness Code of Guidance for Local Authorities: July 2006
title: Homelessness code of guidance for councils: July 2006
body:
The code provides statutory guidance on local authority housing and social services statutory functions in respect of people who are homeless or at risk of homelessness. The code is issued by the Secretaries of State under section 182 of the Housing Act 1996, and local authorities must have regard to the Code, by law.

This is a priced publication available from Communities and Local Government Publications, Cambertown House, Goldthorpe Industrial Estate, Rotherham S63 9BL. Tel: 0300 123 1124, fax: 0300 123 1125, email: product@communities.gsi.gov.uk. Please quote the ISBN when ordering. Alternatively, payment can be made by credit or debit card by calling customer services on 0300 123 1124, open Monday to Friday 08 - 18. Delivery will be 5-7 days from receipt of payment.
attachment_1_title: Homelessness Code of Guidance for Local Authorities (2006)

ignoreDCLG page title: Homelessness Code of Guidance for Local Authorities: Supplementary Guidance on Intentional Homelessness
title: Intentional homelessness: guidance for councils
body: In response to the current economic climate, and the robust framework of financial support the Government has put in place to help homeowners in financial difficulty, this note provides guidance on how local housing authorities should exercise their homelessness functions, and apply the various statutory criteria, when considering whether applicants who are homeless having lost  their home because of difficulties in meeting mortgage commitments are intentionally or unintentionally homeless.
attachment_1_title: Homelessness Code of Guidance for Local Authorities: Supplementary Guidance on Intentional Homelessness

ignoreDCLG page title: Homelessness Legislation: Commencement of Section 314 of, and Schedule 15 to, the Housing and Regeneration Act 2008
title: Housing and Regeneration Act 2008: commencement of Section 314 and Schedule 15
body: This letter informs local housing authorities in England that the government intends to commence section 314 of, and Schedule 15 to, the Housing and Regeneration Act 2008 on 2 March 2009. This will remedy the incompatibility with the European Convention on Human Rights of section 185(4) of the Housing Act 1996, (a provision of the homelessness legislation).
attachment_1_title: Homelessness Legislation: Commencement of Section 314 of, and Schedule 15 to, the Housing and Regeneration Act 2008

ignoreDCLG page title: Homelessness Prevention: A Guide to Good Practice
title: Homelessness prevention: guide to good practice
body:
A good practice guide to inform delivery of homelessness prevention services. This guide is based on an Communities and Local Government commissioned evaluation of homelessness prevention initiatives across ten local authorities and two prisons. The guide provides a number of good practice examples.

This is a priced publication available from Communities and Local Government Publications, Cambertown House, Goldthorpe Industrial Estate, Rotherham S63 9BL. Tel: 0300 123 1124, fax: 0300 123 1125, email: product@communities.gsi.gov.uk. Please quote the ISBN when ordering. Alternatively, payment can be made by credit or debit card by calling customer services on 0300 123 1124, open Monday to Friday 08 - 18. Delivery will be 5-7 days from receipt of payment.
attachment_1_title: Homelessness Prevention: A Guide to Good Practice

ignoreDCLG page title: Homelessness and Health Information Sheet: Dental Services (HIS number 3)
title: Homelessness and health information sheet: dental services
body: Homeless people can face major barriers in accessing dental services - while their life circumstances can often mean they are among those most in need of treatment. This information sheet provides information on how local authorities and health services can work together to provide accessible and appropriate dental services for homeless people.
attachment_1_title: Homelessness and Health Information Sheet: Number 3 - Dental Services

ignoreDCLG page title: Homelessness and Health Information Sheet: Health Visiting services (HIS number 2)
title: Homelessness and health information sheet: health visiting services
body: Homeless people can face great inequalities in accessing health services, yet their health can often suffer from being homeless or living in poor quality temporary accommodation. This information sheet gives information on health visiting services and provides examples of good practice.
attachment_1_title: Homelessness and Health Information Sheet: Number 2 - Health Visiting Services

ignoreDCLG page title: Homelessness and Health Information Sheet: Hospital Discharge (HIS number 4)
title: Homelessness and health information sheet: hospital discharge
body:
Homeless people may often leave health problems untreated until they reach crisis point and then need to rely on treatment at Accident and Emergency (A&E) or will present at other primary health services with multiple and entrenched problems. This combines to make health problems more expensive to treat, hospital and A&E waiting lists longer and can lead to people being less able to support themselves and their families in their accommodation.

This information sheet provides information on how local authorities and health services can work together to provide accessible and appropriate services for homeless people.
attachment_1_title: Homelessness and Health Information Sheet: Number 4 - Hospital Discharge

ignoreDCLG page title: Homelessness and Health Information Sheet: Personal Medical Services (HIS number 1)
title: Homelessness and health information sheet: personal medical services
body:
Homeless people can face great inequalities in accessing health services, yet their health can often suffer from being homeless or living in poor quality temporary accommodation.

This information sheet looks at Personal Medical Services schemes (PMS), which offer opportunities to provide services to groups experiencing difficulty accessing General Medical Services. It presents a number of case studies of successful PMS projects around the country.
attachment_1_title: Homelessness and Health Information Sheet: Number 1 - Personal Medical Services

ignoreDCLG page title: Homelessness prevention and meeting housing need for (ex)offenders: A guide to practice
title: Homelessness prevention and meeting housing needs of ex-offenders
body:
This guide aims to assist those who work with ex-offenders to help prevent them from becoming homeless and to meet their housing needs. It focuses on three main areas:

* partnership working to increase capacity in housing provision,
* multi-agency approaches to assessment and planning,
* and the provision of on-going support.

It draws on existing initiatives to provide examples of practice.
attachment_1_title: Homelessness prevention and meeting housing need for (ex)offenders: A guide to practice

ignoreDCLG page title: Hospital Admission and Discharge: People who are homeless or living in temporary or insecure accommodation
title: Hospital admission and discharge: people who are homeless or living in temporary or insecure accommodation
body: This publication relates to guidance to support hospitals, Primary Care Trusts (PCTs), local authorities and the voluntary sector, working in partnership, to develop an effective admission and discharge protocol for people who are not living in settled accommodation. The over arching aim of the protocol will be to ensure that no one is discharged to the streets or inappropriate accommodation.
attachment_1_title: Hospital Admission and Discharge: People who are homeless or living in temporary or insecure accommodation

ignoreDCLG page title: Hostels Review Toolkit
title: Hostels review toolkit
body: A practical guide to conducting an effective review of hostels services that can be used to improve services.
attachment_1_title: Hostels review toolkit

ignoreDCLG page title: Housing Allocations: Members of the Armed Forces
title: Housing allocations: members of the armed forces
body:
This circular is issued by the Secretary of State to housing authorities in England under s169 of the Housing Act 1996.

The circular provides guidance for authorities when framing their allocation scheme to provide for applications from serving and former members of the Armed Forces and gives effect to a commitment in The Nation's Commitment: Cross-Government Support to our Armed Forces, their Families and Veterans, the Command Paper issued by the Ministry of Defence in July 2008.

Housing authorities are required to have regard to the guidance in exercising their functions under Part 6 of the 1996 Act.
attachment_1_title: Housing allocations - members of the armed forces

ignoreDCLG page title: Housing Disrepair Legal Obligations: Good Practice Guidance
title: Housing disrepair legal obligations: good practice guidance
body:
The purpose of this guidance is to advise on good practice in relation to the management and delivery of housing repairs while emphasising the legal obligations and suggesting appropriate responses where there are threats of litigation.

A high quality repairs service is a key element in the provision of good quality rented housing. Also it is an essential element in achieving high levels of tenant satisfaction, improving the landlord and tenant relationship and protecting health and safety.

A number of local authorities and other landlords have an excellent record in the provision of housing repairs service, but there is scope for improvements, in some cases significant, by many others.  This is a priced publication available from Communities and Local Government Publications, Cambertown House, Goldthorpe Industrial Estate, Rotherham S63 9BL. Tel: 0300 123 1124, fax: 0300 123 1125, email: product@communities.gsi.gov.uk. Please quote the ISBN when ordering. Alternatively, payment can be made by credit or debit card by calling customer services on 0300 123 1124, open Monday to Friday 08 - 18. Delivery will be 5-7 days from receipt of payment.
attachment_1_title: Housing Disrepair Legal Obligations: Good Practice Guidance

ignoreDCLG page title: Housing Health and Safety Rating System: Enforcement Guidance: Housing Act 2004 Part 1: Housing Conditions
title: Housing health and safety rating system enforcement guidance: housing conditions
body:
The Housing Health and Safety Rating System enforcement guidance is given to local housing authorities to provide guidance on the exercise of their duties and powers under Part 1 of the Housing Act 2004.

This is a priced publication available from Communities and Local Government Publications, Cambertown House, Goldthorpe Industrial Estate, Rotherham S63 9BL. Tel: 0300 123 1124, fax: 0300 123 1125, email: product@communities.gsi.gov.uk. Please quote the ISBN when ordering. Alternatively, payment can be made by credit or debit card by calling customer services on 0300 123 1124, open Monday to Friday 08 - 18. Delivery will be 5-7 days from receipt of payment.
attachment_1_title: Housing Health and Safety Rating System: Enforcement Guidance: Housing Act 2004 Part 1: Housing Conditions

ignoreDCLG page title: Housing Injunctions available under the Housing Act 1996
title: Housing injunctions available under the Housing Act 1996
body:
The Anti-social Behaviour Act received Royal Assent on 20 November 2003.

Part 2 of the Act gives social landlords, including local authorities, Housing Action Trusts (HATs) and social landlords registered with the Housing Corporation (RSLs), new and more effective tools to deal with anti-social behaviour. The provisions of Part Two of the Anti-Social Behaviour Act 2003, came into effect in England, by way of a Commencement Order (Statutory Instrument No.1502 (C.61) - 2004) on 30 June 2004. In Wales, Part 2 sections 13, 14 (part) and 16 commenced on 30 September 2004. Sections 12, 14 (remainder) and 15 are expected to commence in March 2005.
attachment_1_title: Housing Injunctions available under the Housing Act 1996

ignoreDCLG page title: Housing and Regeneration Act 2008: Commencement of section 315 - Circumstances when local connection may be established
title: Housing and Regeneration Act 2008: commencement of section 315
body: Section 315 of the Housing and Regeneration Act 2008 ("the 2008 Act") amends section 199 of the Housing Act 1996 ("the 1996 Act").  Section 199 of the 1996 Act sets out the circumstances when a person may establish a "local connection" with a district for the purposes of an application for homelessness assistance under Part 7 of the 1996 Act or an application for social housing under Part 6 of that Act.
attachment_1_title: Housing and Regeneration Act 2008: Commencement of section 315 - Circumstances when local connection may be established

ignoreDCLG page title: Housing renewal: ODPM circular 05/2003
title: Housing renewal: circular ODPM 05/2003
body: Section 315 of the Housing and Regeneration Act 2008 ("the 2008 Act") amends section 199 of the Housing Act 1996 ("the 1996 Act").  Section 199 of the 1996 Act sets out the circumstances when a person may establish a "local connection" with a district for the purposes of an application for homelessness assistance under Part 7 of the 1996 Act or an application for social housing under Part 6 of that Act.
attachment_1_title: Housing renewal: ODPM circular 05/2003

ignoreDCLG page title: Joint working between Housing and Childrens Services: Preventing homelessness and tackling its effects on children and young people
title: Joint working between housing and children services: preventing homelessness
body: The purpose of this guide is to help the managers of Children's Services and Housing Authorities in both single tier and two tier authorities to plan and deliver changes for children, young people and families. It is aimed at senior managers in housing and children's services.
attachment_1_title: Joint working between Housing and Children's Services: Preventing homelessness and tackling its effects on children and young people

ignoreDCLG page title: Landlord accreditation
title: Landlord accreditation
body:
Local authorities up and down the country are increasingly taking a strategic approach to the housing needs of everyone in their community. They recognise the important role of the private rented sector in providing accommodation for a diverse range of households. As part of this new approach, many local authorities are seeking to work with residential landlords and give them a stake in decisions that affect them. This is being done in a number of ways. For example, by offering landlords information that helps them to manage their properties better, by arranging meetings or forums where landlords can exchange views with local authority officers and, increasingly, by setting up voluntary accreditation schemes that recognise and reward landlords who manage their properties to a good standard.

This leaflet looks at the role of accreditation schemes for landlords, the benefits of joining one and where to find more information.

Note on quality: the files attached to this page were converted from a legacy website by automatic process, and may contain minor formatting errors. The text of the document is complete and as originally published.
attachment_1_title: Landlord accreditation

ignoreDCLG page title: Lender notification of repossession proceedings to local authorities: Non-statutory guidance for local housing authorities
title: Lender notification of repossession proceedings to local authorities: non-statutory guidance
body: This guidance is to inform local authorities of the implications of amendments to Civil Procedure Rules Part 55, which will require mortgage lenders to notify local authorities that possession proceedings relating to a mortgaged residential property in their area have commenced and thus to encourage local authorities to use this information in the context of their homelessness prevention functions to assist households at risk of repossession.
attachment_1_title: Lender notification of repossession proceedings to local authorities: Non-statutory guidance for local housing authorities

ignoreDCLG page title: Local Authority Property Search Services - Costing and Charging Guidance
title: Local council property search services: costing and charging guidance
body:
This guidance sets out a methodology for local authorities to charge for access to property search records. In setting costs for property search services, authorities must comply with the Local Authorities (Charges for Property Searches) Regulations 2008 which should be read in conjunction with this document.

The guidance establishes a framework setting out what a local authority can charge for and what it cannot. Using that framework it provides definitions of the type and maturity of data to which the guidance applies. The costing  principles on which it is based are onsistent with existing local authority  accounting arrangements eg BVACoP.

**Note:** The Home Information Pack duties are suspended with immediate effect from 21 May 2010. This means that homes marketed for sale on or after this date will no longer require a Home Information Pack. However, Energy Performance Certificates are still required.
attachment_1_title: Local Authority Property Search Services - Costing and Charging Guidance

ignoreDCLG page title:
Local choice, local control: Statutory guidance on tenant management for local
authorities and local authority tenants
title: Tenant management for local councils and tenants: statutory guidance
body: This guidance is given under the Housing (Right to Manage) Regulations 2008, which provides that all those who are exercising  functions under the Legislation are required to take into account this guidance. It also sets out guidelines for the assessment of competence of a Tenant Management Organisation (TMO).
attachment_1_title: Local choice, local control: Statutory guidance on tenant management for local authorities and local authority tenants

ignoreDCLG page title: Making a difference: Supported lodgings as a housing option for young people
title: Supported lodgings as a housing option for young people
body:
Local councils and their partners are making considerable inroads into the task of meeting the government's target of eliminating the use of bed and breakfast accommodation for 16 and 17 year olds, except in an emergency and then for no more than six weeks. By 30 June 2008 the number staying in bed and breakfast had fallen from approximately 1,000 in September 2006 to 420, 160 of whom had been placed for more than six weeks. Supported lodgings services have played an important role in this in some areas, and Communities and Local Government has supported a number of new services in 2007-08.
The aim of this guide is to inform and support local authorities' planning and commissioning of supported lodgings within the context of strategies to tackle youth homelessness. It is based on a review of supported lodgings services in 17 local authority areas in England, and of data collected through the Supporting People programme.
attachment_1_title: Making a difference: Supported lodgings as a housing option for young people

ignoreDCLG page title: Model Standards 2008 for Caravan Sites in England: Caravan Sites and Control of Development Act 1960  Section 5
title: Model standards for caravan sites in England
body: The model standards represent what is normally to be expected as a matter of good practice on caravan sites. They should be applied with due regard to the particular circumstances of the relevant site, including its physical character, any relevant services, facilities or other amenities that are available within or in the locality of the site and other applicable conditions.
attachment_1_title: Model Standards 2008 for Caravan Sites in England: Caravan Sites and Control of Development Act 1960 - Section 5

ignoreDCLG page title: Modelling business plans for council landlords: local authority financial model user guide
title: Modelling business plans for council landlords: local authority financial model user guide
body:
On 21 July 2009 the Department for Communities and Local Government published a consultation document titled Reform of Council Housing. This included an option of dismantling the current Housing Revenue Account subsidy system and replacing it with a devolved system of financing and accountability termed self-financing. A further consultation titled Council Housing: A real future setting out detailed proposals for self-financing was published on 25 March 2010.

PricewaterhouseCoopers LLP was appointed to provide expert financial and technical support to the project set up to take this proposal forward. This is their report on work to develop a model with values and assumptions which can be used to establish a self-financing valuation for each council and to model business plans for each council.
attachment_1_title: Modelling business plans for council landlords: local authority financial model user guide

ignoreDCLG page title: Modelling business plans for council landlords: Report on model inputs assumptions and outputs - final report
title: Modelling business plans for council landlords: final report on model inputs assumptions and outputs
body:
On 21 July 2009 the Department for Communities and Local Government published a consultation document titled Reform of Council Housing. This included an option of dismantling the current Housing Revenue Account subsidy system and replacing it with a devolved system of financing and accountability termed self-financing. A further consultation titled Council Housing: A real future setting out detailed proposals for self-financing was published on 25 March 2010.

PricewaterhouseCoopers LLP was appointed to provide expert financial and technical support to the project set up to take this proposal forward. This is a spreadsheet which local authorities can use to model council housing business plans under self-financing.
attachment_1_title: Modelling business plans for council landlords: report on model inputs assumptions and outputs - final report
attachment_2_title: Modelling business plans for council landlords: Report on model inputs assumptions and outputs - spreadsheet

ignoreDCLG page title: National Framework for Tenant Participation Compacts
title: National framework for tenant participation compacts
body: The national framework for tenant participation compacts provides a toolkit to help councils and tenants agree and implement effective arrangements for tenant involvement in their area. This updates the original National Framework published in 1999.
attachment_1_title: The National Framework for Tenant Participation Compacts

ignoreDCLG page title: Needs Analysis, Commissioning and Procurement for Housing-Related Support: A resource for housing-related support, social care, and health commissioners
title: Needs analysis, commissioning and procurement for housing-related support
body:
This guide is intended for an audience of local authorities and their partners. It is particularly aimed at commissioners of housing-related support, adult services, health, and probation projects. It will also be relevant to corporate procurement teams, voluntary, user, and community groups and providers of housing-related support for information.

This guide describes the cycles of needs analysis, commissioning, and procurement when applied to housing-related support, and links to the processes used in social care and health commissioning. It is not intended to be a guide to the law as it relates to any of the subjects discussed.
attachment_1_title: Needs Analysis, Commissioning and Procurement for Housing-Related Support: A resource for housing-related support, social care, and health commissioners

ignoreDCLG page title: No One Left Out: Communities ending rough sleeping - Good Practice Notes: Developing a strategic response to prevent and tackle rough sleeping
title: No one left out: communities ending rough sleeping
body: These guidance notes are intended for local authorities who may traditionally not have experienced high numbers of people sleeping rough, or have in place significant levels of specialist provision, but who still need to adopt a strategic response to preventing rough sleeping.
attachment_1_title: No One Left Out: Communities ending rough sleeping - Good Practice Notes: Developing a strategic response to prevent and tackle rough sleeping

ignoreDCLG page title: Options for Setting up a Sanctuary Scheme
title: Options for setting up a sanctuary scheme
body:
The sanctuary scheme is an innovative approach to homelessness prevention. It provides professionally installed security measures to allow those experiencing domestic violence to remain in their own accommodation where it is safe for them to do so, where it is their choice and where the perpetrator no longer lives within the accommodation.

This joint LGA and Department for Communities and Local Government guidance aims to help local authorities and other key stakeholders set up and run effective schemes designed to help victims of domestic violence.
attachment_1_title: Options for Setting up a Sanctuary Scheme

ignoreDCLG page title: Options for the Future of the Household Projection Model: A final report
title: Options for the future of the household projection model: final report
body:
The Department for Communities and Local Government 'household projection model' is used to generate household projections using the latest Office for National Statistics sub-national population projections, with the outputs used as a key element of the evidence base for housing and planning.

The national household projections are the Government's official long term view of the future if demographic trends were to continue, and are particularly important in supporting policy development and enabling regional and local bodies to plan their housing and other services.
attachment_1_title: Options for the Future of the Household Projection Model: A final report

ignoreDCLG page title: P1E Guidance: Homelessness Prevention and Relief: Recording cases where positive action is taken to prevent or relieve homelessness
title: Homelessness prevention and relief: P1E guidance
body:
This note provides guidance (first issued in April 2008) for local housing authorities about recording cases where homelessness is prevented or relieved for the purpose of the P1E data return. It supersedes the guidance issued in July 2005 in respect of BVPI 213, which ceased to apply from April 2008.

This guidance will also be of relevance to partner organisations who work with, or on behalf of, local authorities to prevent and relieve homelessness. The aim of this note is to assist local authorities in the completion of section 10 of the P1E, and it is non-statutory guidance.
attachment_1_title: P1E Guidance: Homelessness Prevention and Relief Recording cases where positive action is taken to prevent or relieve homelessness

ignoreDCLG page title: Personal searches of the local land charges register and other records held by local authorities: Good practice guidance for local authorities and personal searchers
title: Personal searches of the local land charges register and other records held by local authorities
body:
This good practice guide provides advice to local authorities and personal searchers on providing access to property information held by local authorities used in property searches.

It follows on from the consultation paper Delivering Property Searches: Good practice guidance for Local Authorities and personal searchers published in May 2007.

**Note:** The Home Information Pack duties are suspended with immediate effect from 21 May 2010. This means that homes marketed for sale on or after this date will no longer require a Home Information Pack. However, Energy Performance Certificates are still required.
attachment_1_title: Personal searches of the local land charges register and other records held by local authorities: Good practice guidance for local authorities and personal searchers

ignoreDCLG page title: Preventing Homelessness: A Strategy Health Check
title: Preventing homelessness: a strategy health check
body:
As well helping local housing authorities review their homelessness strategy and establish how effective their services are in tackling and preventing homelessness, the toolkit also looks at how to tackle some of the wider causes of homelessness which Housing Quality Network (HQN) identified as gaps in their evaluation of the 2003 strategies.

Authorities may also find the assessment tool useful in developing plans to meet the Government's target of reducing temporary accommodation by 50 per cent by 2010, and in assessing how robust their action plans are for meeting the aims of the Government's broader homelessness strategy.
attachment_1_title: Preventing Homelessness: A Strategy Health Check

ignoreDCLG page title: Private Finance Initiative Schemes for HRA/Non HRA Housing: Guidance for Authorities Making Proposals
title: Private finance initiative schemes for council housing
body: The Spending Review 2004 announced Â£1.22 billion new Private Finance Initiative (PFI) credits for Local Authorities to refurbish homes and increase social housing for rent. This Guidance tells local authorities how to apply for these credits. The letter that went out with this guidance is also available as a download.
attachment_1_title: Private Finance Initiative Schemes for HRA/Non HRA Housing: Guidance for Authorities Making Proposals
attachment_2_title: Letter to Chief Executives and Housing Directors of all Local Authorities in England

ignoreDCLG page title: Provision of accommodation for 16 and 17 year old young people who may be homeless and/or require accommodation
title: Provision of accommodation for 16 and 17 year olds who may be homeless and/or require accommodation
body: Statutory guidance was issued on 1 April 2010 to local authorities jointly by the Secretary of State for Children, Schools and Families and the Secretary of State for Communities and Local Government. It provides revised guidance for children's services authorities and local housing authorities about their respective duties under Part 3 of the Children Act 1989 and Part 7 of the Housing Act 1996 to secure or provide accommodation for homeless 16 and 17 year old children, following the judgment by the House of Lords in the case of R(G) v London Borough of Southwark (2009).
attachment_1_title: Provision of accommodation for 16 and 17 year old young people who may be homeless and/or require accommodation

ignoreDCLG page title: Recording Homelessness Prevention and relief at E10 of the P1E Quarterly Return: Further guidance for local housing authorities
title: Recording homelessness prevention and relief
body: This note provides further non-statutory guidance for local housing authorities on how to record for the P1E quarterly return cases where homelessness is prevented or relieved. It supplements the guidance issued by the Department for Communities and Local Government in April 2008, and has been produced to coincide with the publication of the first set of data on local authority performance on preventing and relieving homelessness, taken from the P1E returns. This guidance is also likely to be helpful for local authorities' partner organisations.
attachment_1_title: Recording Homelessness Prevention and relief at E10 of the P1E Quarterly Return: Further guidance for local housing authorities

ignoreDCLG page title: Reducing the risks - The Housing Health and Safety Rating System
title: Reducing the risks: the housing health and safety rating system
body:
The housing health and safety rating system is a new risk assessment tool used to assess potential risks to the health and safety of occupants in residential properties in England and Wales. The legislation came into effect in England on 6 April 2006 and will come into effect in Wales later in 2006.

The new assessment method focuses on the hazards that are present in housing. Tackling these hazards will make housing healthier and safer to live in.
attachment_1_title: Reducing the risks - The Housing Health and Safety Rating System

ignoreDCLG page title: Regulatory Impact Assessment: Housing Act 2004 - Part 1: Housing Conditions
title: Regulatory impact assessment of the housing health and safety rating system
body: This document assesses the costs and benefits of the new housing health and safety rating system regime in Part 1 of the Housing Act 2004.
attachment_1_title: Regulatory Impact Assessment: Housing Act 2004 Part 1: Housing Conditions

ignoreDCLG page title:
Residents choice: Guidance on tenant management and other options supported
through the Tenant Empowerment Programme
title: Tenant empowerment programme: guidance
body: This handbook gives guidance to residents living in social housing who are considering taking control of housing and related services. It looks at how residents can get advice and consider their choices for having more influence over services in their neighbourhood. It explains how to setup a tenant management organisation or negotiate a local management agreement.

ignoreDCLG page title: Social Housing Fraud Communications Toolkit
title: Social housing fraud campaign materials
body:
To help deliver the campaign locally Communities and Local Government have produced a marketing toolkit for local authorities and social housing landlords.

The toolkit contains template leaflets and posters that are fully adaptable to include landlord's logos and contact details. Amending, printing and distribution of the marketing materials are the responsibility of the social housing landlord. Examples of the toolkit posters and leaflets are available for download below.

Adobe InDesign formats are required to adapt the leaflets and posters for local use. If you are a local authority or social housing landlord you may order the free InDesign format disk of the toolkit, by quoting: the product code (listed above), your name, your organisation and your delivery address.

This publication is available free of charge from Communities and Local Government Publications, Cambertown House, Goldthorpe Industrial Estate, Rotherham S63 9BL. Tel: 0300 123 1124, fax: 0300 123 1125, email: product@communities.gsi.gov.uk. Please quote the product code when ordering. Delivery will be 5 to 7 days from receipt of order. A maximum quantity restriction may apply. For an enquiry about your order please contact customer services on 0300 123 1124, open Monday to Friday 08:00 â€“ 18:00.
attachment_1_title: Social Housing Fraud Communications Toolkit
attachment_2_title: Help Stop Housing Cheats (poster)
attachment_3_title: Help Stop Housing Cheats (leaflet)
attachment_4_title: Blow the whistle on housing cheats (poster)
attachment_5_title: Blow the whistle on housing cheats (leaflet)

ignoreDCLG page title: Supplement to 'Managing Unauthorised Camping: A Good Practice Guide'
title: Managing unauthorised camping: guidance supplement
body: The good practice guide Managing Unauthorised Camping was originally published in February 2004. It was intended to be updated when consultation on the new provisions introduced in the Anti-social Behaviour Act 2003 (amending the Criminal Justice and Public Order Act 1994) was complete. This consultation has now ended, and this supplement provides guidance on the new provisions.
attachment_1_title: Supplement to the Guidance on Managing Unauthorised Camping

ignoreDCLG page title: Supplement to the Guidance on Arms Length Management
title: Arms length management: guidance supplement
body:
This is a supplement to the Guidance on the Arms Length Management Organisation (ALMO) option for local authorities that wish to improve their housing management services and seek additional resources to invest in bringing their housing stock up to the decent homes standard.

The guidance was issued by the Office of the Deputy Prime Minister in October 2004 and continues to cover the key policy and operational features of ALMOs, setting out the criteria for bids for additional resources in Round 6 of the programme.
attachment_1_title: Supplement to the Guidance on Arms Length Management

ignoreDCLG page title: Supplement to the Housing Transfer Manual - 2006 Programme

body: Section and paragraph numbers in this supplement indicate where the additional or amended guidance fits into the Housing Transfer Manual 2005 Programme, ODPM October 2004 Product code 04HC02613.

ignoreDCLG page title: Supporting People financial benefits model documentation and user guide
title: Supporting people financial benefits model
body:
The purpose of this document is to explain the logic behind, and form a user guide for, the Supporting People local financial benefits model built by Capgemini for the Department for Communities and Local Government.

The document's target audience is users from local authorities who wish to become familiar with the model so that, on an ongoing basis they can:

* update the data it contains
* easily read and interpret its output
attachment_1_title: Supporting People financial benefits model documentation and user guide
attachment_2_title: Supporting People local financial benefits model (Spreadsheet)

ignoreDCLG page title: Tackling Homelessness Amongst Ethnic Minority Households - A Development Guide
title: Tackling homelessness among ethnic minorities
body: This guide aims to assist local authorities and their partner agencies in the development of inclusive, evidence-based and cost-effective homelessness services for their local ethnic minority populations. This document is related to the ODPM-commissioned research the Causes of Homelessness Amongst Ethnic Minority Populations.
attachment_1_title: Tackling Homelessness Amongst Ethnic Minority Households - A Development Guide

ignoreDCLG page title: Tackling Overcrowding in England: Lessons from the London pilot schemes and sub-regional coordination
title: Tackling overcrowding in england: lessons from the London pilots
body:
This note summarises the lessons learned so far from 5 Department for Communities and Local Government-funded pilot schemes in London and work to strengthen capacity to address overcrowding in each of the 5 London sub-regions.

This piece of work highlights good practice and provides practical support to local authorities and registered social landlordsto assist efforts to tackle overcrowding where the problems are most acute.
attachment_1_title: Tackling Overcrowding in England: Lessons from the London pilot schemes and sub-regional coordination

ignoreDCLG page title: Tackling Overcrowding in England: Self-Assessment for Local Authorities
title: Tackling overcrowding in england: self assessment for councils
body:
Living in overcrowded accommodation can have a devastating effect on families. If a home is overcrowded it can affect health and educational attainment and can impact negatively on life chances.
In December 2007 the government outlined its strategy to tackle overcrowding. This self-assessment toolkit is intended to support housing providers by offering practical tips on how to develop their own strategy and action plan to assist those households worst affected by overcrowding.
attachment_1_title: Tackling Overcrowding in England: Self-Assessment for Local Authorities

ignoreDCLG page title: Tackling anti-social behaviour: Tools and powers  toolkit for social landlords
title: Tackling anti-social behaviour: tools and powers for social landlords
body:
This guidance consolidates in a single document with disparate sources of advice to provide a comprehensive reference point for social landlords of the key tools and powers available to them to tackle anti-social behaviour.

The main body of the guidance provides details of individual tools and powers in a factsheet format. The guidance also considers social landlords' role in tackling anti-social behaviour as an aid to strategic development of anti-social behaviour services and suggests the broad approach that landlords should adopt in protecting communities from anti-social behaviour.
attachment_1_title: Tackling anti-social behaviour: Tools and powers - toolkit for social landlords

ignoreDCLG page title: Tackling unlawful subletting and occupancy: Good practice guidance for social landlords

ignoreDCLG page title: The Future Home Improvement Agency - Handyperson services report
title: Future Home Improvement Agency report on handyperson services
body:
This is a report on handyperson services, including benefits, steps in setting up services and key issues for service providers.
It is one of a series of reports from the Future Home Improvement Agency project pulling together good practice and setting out a broad agenda for the evolution of the sector.
attachment_1_title: The Future Home Improvement Agency - Handyperson services report

ignoreDCLG page title: The Future Home Improvement Agency: Supporting choice and maintaining independence - A report overview
title: Future Home Improvement Agency report on supporting choice and maintaining independence
body:
This report gives an overview of the key findings of the Future Home Improvement Agency project carried out by Foundations on behalf of the Department for Communities and Local Government.â€¨Home improvement agencies help vulnerable people to maintain their independence. Their primary focus is the repair or adaptation of the client's home, and in support of this objective they may provide a range of services depending on local needs and circumstances.

The Future Home Improvement Agency project aims to set out a broad agenda for the evolution of the sector to its next level. It highlights what is already being done well by home improvement agencies and suggests models for wider application.
attachment_1_title: The Future Home Improvement Agency: Supporting choice and maintaining independence - A report overview

ignoreDCLG page title: The Housing (Right to Manage) Regulations 1994 (Circular)
title: The Housing (Right to Manage) Regulations 1994: circular
body:
This Circular is issued in connection with the Housing (Right to Manage) Regulations 1994.

The Regulations, which are made under section 27 AB of the Housing Act 1985 (inserted by section 132 of the Leasehold Reform, Housing and Urbanâ€¨Development Act 1993) require local housing authorities to act inâ€¨accordance with guidance issued by the Secretary of State.

The guidance of theâ€¨Secretary of State is set out in the Annex to this circular. This circular does notâ€¨reiterate all the matters covered by the Regulations and guidance: both need to be studied. This circular is intended neither as an authoritative nor comprehensive account of the law, nor a substitute for the source legislative material.
attachment_1_title: The Housing (Right to Manage) Regulations 1994 (Circular)

ignoreDCLG page title: Tolerated Trespassers: Guidance for social landlords
title: Tolerated trespassers: guidance for social landlords
body:
This guidance is designed to support social landlords in implementing the tolerated trespasser provisions in section 299 and Schedule 11 to the Housing and Regeneration Act 2008 and the Housing (Replacement of Terminated Tenancies) (Successor Landlords) (England) Order 2009.

It is intended primarily for those local housing authorities which continue to own housing stock, for Arms Length Management Organisations and for Registered Social Landlords. The guidance provides information about the provisions in the 2008 Act and the Order and about those factors which social landlords may wish to consider when implementing the provisions.
attachment_1_title: Tolerated Trespassers: Guidance for social landlords

ignoreDCLG page title: Vacant Dwellings NeSS Validation Document 2005
title: Vacant dwellings dataset validation
body:
This document was produced to give users of the Vacant Dwellings dataset a thorough understanding of the rigorous data cleaning that was established by the year 2005.

Users of the Neighbourhood Statistics (NeSS) website will be linked to this document from the metadata file stored on the NeSS website. It is the sole source of information as to the validation procedures undertaken by DCLG to maintain the validity of the data and ensure the dataset is suitable for publication by ONS.
attachment_1_title: Vacant Dwellings NeSS Validation Document 2005

title: Working hostels: models of provision
body: 'No One Left Out: communities ending rough sleeping' set out the intention to test new approaches and pathways including development of hostels geared towards supporting and stabilising people in employment.â€¨â€¨A working hostel is anticipated to be a stepping-stone enabling residents to move on from rough sleeping into work or into alternative housing pathways.

ignoreDCLG page title: Handypersons Financial Benefits Toolkit
title: Handypersons financial benefits toolkit
body:
The Handyperson financial benefits toolkit uses available evidence on the aims, objectives, outcomes and benefits of handyperson services and similar interventions to help put together a case for the future funding of handyperson services locally. It uses an approach to estimating the benefits of social policy interventions that has previously been used in a number of areas and will be familiar to anyone who has used the supporting people financial benefits model.

This guidance is provided as an aid for using the tool for developing a business case for handyperson services. Handyperson services are complex in nature, varying across local authority areas and in the nature of services interventions delivered. The examples and guidance provided are not intended to be exhaustive but are aimed at providing a checklist of key details to be included within the business case.
attachment_1_title: Handypersons Financial Benefits Toolkit
attachment_2_title: Handypersons Financial Benefits Toolkit

ignoreDCLG page title: Right to Buy - The Use of Discretionary Powers on Repayment of Discount
title: Right to Buy: use of discretionary powers on repayment of discount
body:
Under section 155 of the Housing Act 1985, former social tenants who dispose of a property within a specified period after purchasing it under the Right to Buy scheme have to repay upon demand by the former landlord all or part of the discount they received on purchase, unless it is an exempted disposal. Section 185 of the Housing Act 2004 amends section 155 by extending the specified period from 3 years to 5 years. Section 155 (as amended) and the new section 155B also apply to the Rent to Mortgage scheme.

Section 185 of the 2004 Act also clarifies that former landlords have discretion not to demand that former social tenants should repay part or all of the discount they received. This note offers guidance on when in the government's view it might be appropriate to exercise this discretion.

**Note:** this document was updated in updated in January 2010.
attachment_1_title: Right to buy - the use of discretionary powers on repayment of discount

ignoreDCLG page title: Addendum to the General power for local authorities to trade in function related activities through a company: Guidance on the Power in the Local Government Act 2003 - Amendments to paragraphs 1-30
title: General power for local authorities to trade in function related activities through a company: addendum

ignoreDCLG page title: Application for provisional approval of byelaws (proforma)
title: Application for provisional approval of byelaws
body:
This proforma application for provisional approval must be completed in respect of every byelaw application.

Its purpose is to assist councils by providing them with an aide memoire of the issues to be addressed and to help the Department for Communities and Local Government by providing confirmation that attention has been given to those issues.

ignoreDCLG page title: Best Value Guidance for National Parks Authorities Circular 10/2003 (Defra Circular 03/2003)
title: Best value guidance for National Parks Authorities: Circular Defra 10/2003
body:
This guidance sets out how National Park Authorities (NPAs) in England and the Broads Authority might meet the requirements of Part I of the Local Government Act 1999 to make arrangements to secure continuous improvement in their functions, with regard to efficiency, effectiveness and economy. It replaces DETR Circulars 10/99 and 02/01.

Paragraphs 23-40 and Annexes B, C, D and E consist of statutory guidance provided under Section 3 (the general duty), Section 5 (Best Value Reviews), Section 6 (Best Value Performance Plans), and Section 19 (Contracts: exclusion of noncommercial considerations) of the 1999 Act.
attachment_1_title: Best Value Guidance for National Parks Authorities Circular 10/2003 (Defra Circular 03/2003)

ignoreDCLG page title: Building on Strong Foundations - A Framework for Local Authority Asset Management
title: Framework for local authority asset management
body:
Asset management has a strong role to play in establishing the vision for an area and the strategy will aim to show how it can underpin the visions set out in the sustainable community strategy, local area agreement and the local development framework.  The strategy will look at the all performance of assets and how they can be used to deliver efficiency gains set out by national improvement and efficiency strategy and delivering value for money in local government strategy.

In the current tight fiscal climate, effective and efficient asset management is a key element in the drive to improve service delivery and achieve efficiency gains.
attachment_1_title: Building on Strong Foundations - A Framework for Local Authority Asset Management

ignoreDCLG page title: Business Rate Supplements guidance: additionality and ballots
title: Business rates supplements guidance: additionality and ballots
body: The Business Rate Supplements Act 2009 makes provision for county councils, unitary district councils and the Greater London Authority to levy a supplement on the national non-domestic rate (or business rate). Authorities will be able to use the proceeds to fund additional investment aimed at promoting the economic development of local areas.
attachment_1_title: Business Rate Supplements guidance: additionality and ballots

ignoreDCLG page title: Business Rate Supplements: guidance for Local Authorities
title: Business rates supplements: guidance
body: The Business Rate Supplements Act 2009 makes provision for county councils, unitary district councils and the Greater London Authority to levy a supplement on the national non-domestic rate (or business rate). Authorities will be able to use the proceeds to fund additional investment aimed at promoting the economic development of local areas.
attachment_1_title: Business Rate Supplements: guidance for Local Authorities

ignoreDCLG page title: Business Rates Deferral Scheme: Administrative Guidance
title: Business rates deferral scheme: guidance
body: The Non-Domestic Rating (Deferred Payments) (England) Regulations 2009 came into force on 31 July 2009 at which point businesses could apply for deferral. This guidance provides details on the processing of applications, eligibility, the calculation of the deferrable amount, and billing and enforcement.
attachment_1_title: Business Rates Deferral Scheme: Administrative Guidance

ignoreDCLG page title: Council Tax Consultation - Guidelines for Local Authorities
title: Council Tax consultations with the public: guidelines
body: These guidelines are designed to assist local authorities in consulting the public on council tax. While guidelines on consultation are available, little has been produced that is specific to consulting on local tax and spend issues - an area that presents particular difficulties. This document draws on the experience of councils and debates with practitioners to provide practical support to those authorities committed to carrying out quality and effective consultation on council tax and budget matters.
attachment_1_title: Council Tax Consultation - Guidelines for Local Authorities - June 2002

ignoreDCLG page title: DCLG Circular 03/2006 - Guidance on the Accounts and Audit Regulations 2003
title: Accounts and Audit Regulations 2003: circular 03/2006
body:
The purpose of this guidance is to assist relevant bodies and smaller relevant bodies in their operation of the accounting regime under the Accounts and Audit Regulations 2003.

This circular seeks to provide guidance on the issue of proper accounting practices and details of where generally recognised published codes setting out proper accounting practices may be found. It also seeks to provide guidance on new requirements introduced by the amendments to the 2003 regulations.

This is a priced publication available from TSO (The Stationery Office), PO Box 29, Norwich NR3 1GN. Order through the Parliamentary Hotline (Lo-call): 08457 023 474, fax: 0870 600 5533, textphone 0870 240 3701, email: book.orders@tso.co.uk or visit www.tsoshop.co.uk to buy online.
attachment_1_title: DCLG Circular 03/2006 - Guidance on the Accounts and Audit Regulations 2003

ignoreDCLG page title: General power for best value authorities to charge for discretionary services - guidance on the power in the Local Government Act 2003
title: General power for best value authorities to charge for discretionary services: guidance
body:
This guidance aims to assist local authorities in England on charging for discretionary services, as authorised under section 93 and 94 of the Local Government Act 2003.

This is guidance issued under section 93 (6) of the act, to which authorities are required to pay regard.
attachment_1_title: General power for best value authorities to charge for discretionary services

ignoreDCLG page title: General power for local authorities to trade in function related activities through a company - guidance on the power in the Local Government Act 2003
title: General power for local authorities to trade in function-related activities through a company: guidance
body:
This guidance aims to assist local authorities in England on trading through a company, as authorised for the purpose of carrying on their ordinary functions under section 95 and 96 of the Local Government Act - the local government (best value authorities) (power to trade) (England) Order 2004 (S.I 2004/1705) (the trading order).

This guidance explains how, in the view of the Secretary of State, issues in relations to trading may be handled.

This is statutory guidance issued under section 92 (2) of the Act, to which authorities are required to pay regard.
attachment_1_title: General power for local authorities to trade in function related activities hrough a company

ignoreDCLG page title: Guidance on community governance reviews
title: Community governance reviews: guidance
body:
The Local Government and Public Involvement in Health Act 2007 (Part 4) devolved power from the Secretary of State to principal councils to carry out community governance reviews and put in place or make changes to local community governance arrangements.

This guidance is intended to provide assistance to principal councils on undertaking community governance reviews and making recommendations on electoral arrangements for parish councils.
attachment_1_title: Guidance on community governance reviews

ignoreDCLG page title: Guidance to Local Areas in England on Pooling and Aligning Budgets
title: Pooling and aligning local budgets: guidance
body:
This guidance provides clarity on pooling and aligning budgets and on related issues often cited as difficult. It brings together current experience and learning from across different sectors with existing guidance to provide information and help. It also provides case studies and best practice examples, and links to additional help. It should be of interest to local partnerships such as:

* a Local Strategic Partnership
* Children's Trust Board
* a community Safety Partnership or
* any local body that wants to look at the possibility of joint financing arrangements with other local partners
attachment_1_title: Guidance to local areas in England on pooling and aligning budgets

ignoreDCLG page title: Model Reorganisation of Community Governance Order
title: Model reorganisation of community governance order
body: This model reorganisation of community governance order is published alongside the guidance on community governance reviews to assist local authorities when implementing decisions made following their reviews. The model order is offered on an advisory basis to help councils drawing up their orders but they are not obliged to follow this example. Principal councils will still want to seek their own legal advice that any orders they produce meets the necessary legal requirements.
attachment_1_title: Model Reorganisation of Community Governance Order

ignoreDCLG page title: Model byelaw 10 - Byelaws for markets
title: Byelaws for markets: model byelaw 10
body:
Section 60 of the Food Act 1984 provides for a local authority who maintain a market to make byelaws for:

* market days and hours
* prevention of obstruction
* authority to use space
* maintaining cleanliness
* prevention of spread of fire
* preservation of order
* use of water taps
* animals and livestock

As the legislation requires the local authority to consult the fire authority, draft byelaws should be accompanied by confirmation that this has been done.
attachment_1_title: Model byelaw 10
attachment_2_title: Model byelaw 10: guidance notes

ignoreDCLG page title: Model byelaw 2 - Pleasure grounds, public walks and open spaces
title: Pleasure grounds, public walks and open spaces: model byelaw 2
body:
Section 164 of the Public Health Act 1875 and section 15 of the Open Spaces Act 1906 enable local authorities to make byelaws for the regulation of public walks and pleasure grounds and of open spaces and burial grounds respectively.

Section 12 of the Open Spaces Act 1906 extends the types of land for which byelaws can be made under section 15 of that Act.

Byelaws should be adopted only as genuinely required to address an existing problem. If councils are in doubt about the layout of the byelaws they are advised to use the standard scheme and not seal the byelaws until they have received the approval of the Secretary of State.
attachment_1_title: Model byelaw 2
attachment_2_title: Model byelaw 2: guidance notes
attachment_3_title: Flowchart 1: enabling powers for pleasure ground and open spaces byelaws
attachment_4_title: Flowchart 2: enabling powers for commons and town or village greens

ignoreDCLG page title: Model byelaw 3 - Amusement premises
title: Amusement premises: model byelaw 3
body:
Section 75 of the Public Health Act 1961, as amended by section 22 of the Local Government (Miscellaneous Provisions) Act 1976 enable local authorities to make byelaws for the regulation of Amusement Premises.

The model byelaws belows contain complex and detailed technical information which is deemed essential to preserve public safety and uniform standards throughout the country and should be maintained as far as possible. Local variation on matters of public safety is not desirable. The byelaws should, therefore, be adopted as a package without deviation. The Secretary of State will not normally confirm byelaws which deviate from these models.

The model set includes byelaws on regulation of opening hours; safe egress, nuisance, cleanliness, order and public safety and fire prevention.
attachment_1_title: Model byelaw 3
attachment_2_title: Model byelaw 3: guidance notes

ignoreDCLG page title: Model byelaw 4 - Pleasure fairs
title: Pleasure fairs: model byelaw 4
body:
Section 75 of the Public Health Act 1961, as amended by section 22 of the Local Government (Miscellaneous Provisions) Act 1976 enable local authorities to make byelaws to control pleasure fairs.

The model byelaws below contain complex and detailed technical information which is deemed essential to preserve public safety. Uniform standards throughout the country should be maintained as far as possible, both for the safety of the public and because those operating travelling fairs cannot be expected to familiarise themselves with a variety of byelaw regimes. Local variation on matters of public safety is not desirable. The byelaws should, therefore, be adopted as a package without deviation. The Secretary of State will not  confirm byelaws which deviate from these models.

This model set includes byelaws on regulation of opening hours; notice of intention to hold a pleasure fair; fire prevention, safe ingress; sanitary conditions, cleanliness, order and public safety.
attachment_1_title: Model byelaw 4
attachment_2_title: Model byelaw 4: guidance notes

ignoreDCLG page title: Model byelaw 5 - Promenades
title: Promenades: model byelaw 5
body:
Section 83 of the Public Health Acts Amendment Act 1907 enables local authorities to make byelaws to regulate the user of any promenade and to provide for the preservation of order and good conduct for the purpose of preventing danger, obstruction or annoyance to persons using the promenade.

Byelaws should not be adopted en bloc, but only as genuinely required to address an existing problem. If councils are in doubt about the layout of the byelaws they are advised to use the standard scheme and not seal the byelaws until they have received the approval of the Secretary of State.

This model set includes byelaws on cycling, interference with life saving equipment, kites and buggies, motor vehicles, protection of flower beds, removal of signs and structures, skateboarding,  trading and unauthorised erection of structures.
attachment_1_title: Model byelaw 5
attachment_2_title: Model byelaw 5: guidance notes

ignoreDCLG page title: Model byelaw 6 - The seashore
title: The seashore: model byelaw 6
body:
Section 82 of the Public Health Acts Amendment Act 1907 enables district councils  to make byelaws to regulate the user of the seashore and to provide for the preservation of order and good conduct for the purpose of preventing danger, obstruction or annoyance to persons using the seashore.

Byelaws should not be adopted en bloc, but only as genuinely required to address an existing problem. If councils are in doubt about the layout of the byelaws they are advised to use the standard scheme and not seal the byelaws until they have received the approval of the Secretary of State.

This model set includes byelaws on aircraft, bait digging, fires, fishing, games, horse riding, interference with life-saving equipment, public shows and performances,  removal signs and structures, sandlines, trading and  unauthorised erection of structures.
attachment_1_title: Model byelaw 6
attachment_2_title: Model byelaw 6: guidance notes

ignoreDCLG page title: Model byelaw 8 - Good rule and government
title: Good rule and government: model byelaw 8
body:
Section 235 of the Local Government Act 1972 enables district and borough councils to make byelaws for the good rule and government of the whole or any part of the district or borough and for the prevention and suppression of nuisances.

This model set includes byelaws on climbing upon and hanging from bridges, fairground attractions causing obstruction to traffic, dangerous games near and on highways, interference with  life saving equipment and road warning lamps, riding on road margins, skateboarding, touting, and urinating in public.
attachment_1_title: Model byelaw 8
attachment_2_title: Model byelaw 8: guidance notes

ignoreDCLG page title: ODPM Circular 02/2004: Addendum to 03/2003 - Local Government Act 1999: Part 1
title: Local Government Act 1999 Part 1: circular ODPM 02/2004
body:
With the exception of Police authorities, the following guidance applies to all best value authorities in England. It explains how these authorities might meet the requirements of Part I of the Local Government Act 1999 in preparing Best Value Performance Plans.

Paragraphs 3-18 and Annex A consist of statutory guidance and replace paragraphs 65-76 and Annex E of Circular 03/2003.
attachment_1_title: ODPM Circular 02/2004: Addendum to 03/2003 -Local Government Act 1999: Part 1

ignoreDCLG page title: ODPM Circular 03/2003: Best Value Performance Improvement
title: Best value and performance improvement: circular ODPM 03/2003
body:
This circular applies to all principal local authorities in England. It provides guidance on how they might meet the requirements of Part I of the Local Government Act 1999.

It replaces DETR Circulars 10/99 and 02/01. Paragraphs 28 to 76 and annexes C, D and E consist of statutory guidance provided under Section 3 (the general duty), Section 5 (Best Value Reviews), Section 6 (Best Value Performance Plans) and Section 19 (Contracts: exclusion of non-commercial considerations) of the 1999 Act.
attachment_1_title: ODPM Circular 03/2003: Best Value Performance Improvement - with 2004 addendums

ignoreDCLG page title: ODPM Circular 05/2006: Local Government Act 1999: Part 1 Best Value and Performance Improvement
title: Best value and performance improvement: circular ODPM 05/2006
body:
It explains how these authorities might meet the requirements of Part I of the Local Government Act 1999 in preparing Best Value Performance Plans. Paragraphs 3-6 and Annex A and B consist of statutory guidance and replace paragraphs 13-16 and Annex A and B of Circular 02/2004.

This is a priced publication available from TSO (The Stationery Office), PO Box 29, Norwich NR3 1GN. Order through the Parliamentary Hotline (Lo-call): 08457 023 474, fax: 0870 600 5533, textphone 0870 240 3701, email: book.orders@tso.co.uk or visit www.tsoshop.co.uk to buy online.

ignoreDCLG page title: Planning Together: Updated practical guide for local strategic partnerships and planners
title: Planning together: guidance for local strategic partnerships and planners
body:
This publication is aimed at local council leaders, planners, local strategic partnership co-ordinators and elected members. It is a short practical guide focused on the strategic leadership role of local authorities working through local strategic partnership and the planning system to shape good places and deliver quality services.

The Planning Advisory Service has worked alongside the preparation of this guide to develop a web-based [case study library](http://www.pas.gov.uk/pas/core/page.do?pageId=33649 â€œPlanning Advisory Service: case study libraryâ€).
attachment_1_title: Planning Together: Updated practical guide for local strategic partnerships and planners

ignoreDCLG page title: Power to promote well-being of the area: Statutory guidance for local councils
title: Power to promote well-being of the area: statutory guidance for local councils
body: This guidance is aimed at English local councils (parish, town, village, neighbourhood, and community councils) and discusses the extension to eligible local councils of the Power to Promote or Improve Economic, Social, or Environmental Well-Being (colloquially known as the "well-being power").
attachment_1_title: Power to promote well-being of the area: Statutory guidance for local councils
